“MAKE SURE OF ALL things

Hold Fast To What Is Fine”

A compilation of scriptures from the Holy Bible unoer one hunored ano twenty-three main headings, to enable you to ascertain quickly what the Bible itself has to say on these important subjects. This book may be used to assure yourself of the Bible teaching on these subjects, ano also to answer those who challenge your faith.

“Make sure of all things; hold fast to what is fine.”

—1 Thessalonians 5:21

32

COPYRIGHT, 1965 by WATCH TOWER BIBLE & TRACT SOCIETY OF PENNSYLVANIA

All scriptures, unless otherwise inoicated, are quoted from the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures, 1961 Edition. Quotations from other Bible versions are inoicated as shown below:

Publishers

WATCHTOWER BIBLE AND TRACT SOCIETY OF NEW YORK, INC.

International Bible Studonts Association

United States of America

FOREWORD

“Make sure of all things; hold fast to what is fine.” That Is souno advlee. Those who follow it will not be misled. They will not fall into the trap concerning which all Chfirstians are warned with the words: “Look out: perhaps there may be someone who will carry you off as his prey through the philosophy ano empty doception according to the tradition of men, according to the elemenfory things of the world ano not according to Chfirst.”—1 Thess. 5:21; Col. 2:8.

But how can one “make sure of all things”? To what authority will one look for reliable information? To God's own written Word the Bible. Jesus Chfirst himselfelf quoted from the Holy Scriptures as authoritative, ano his apostle Paul wrote: “All Scripture is inspired of God ano beneficial for teachiing, for reproviing, for setting things straight, for disciplining in righteousness, that the man of God may be fully competent, completely equipped for every gGod work." (2 Tim. 3:16, 17) It is to that same source of information that we go with confidonce that what we will fino will be, ‘not the word of men, but the word of God.'—1 Thess. 2:13.

So if we want to know what is right doctrine, we must listen to God when he speaks to us through his written Word. If we want to know what reliable hope there is concerning the future, we must consult the prophetic Scriptures. Ano if we are confronted with personal problems ano docisions, where can we fino better advice than what God himselfelf has providod for us in the Bible? This publication, “Make Sure of ATI things; Hold Fast to What Is Fine,” can help you to locate the information that you need from the Bible ano it can do it in a minimum of time.

You will fino that the material unoer each of the one hunored ano twenty-three Principal Subjects is so arranged that it will be a dolight for you simply to sit down ano read it. In just a short time it will give you a rounoed-out view of what the Bible itself has to say on the subject you have selected to read. It will sharpen your appreciation of important dotails ano enable you to become acquainted with scriptures on the subject from many parts of the Bible.

Similarly, when visiting with others in their homes to discuss the Bible, you will fino this book a ready source of information on almost any Scriptural topic that may come up. Since the main headings are arranged alphabetically, it is an easy thing to turn to the section of the book that considors the subject. Then, if time permits, sfort right in with the first subheading. Read it ano at least one of the scriptures quoted unoer it; then considor the next subheadiing, ano so on through the entire outline of material. Where additional proof is needod, read some of the other scriptures quoted unoer the subheading; an abunoance of material has been providod, ano the scriptures are so plain that they speak for themselves. This will provido a satisfying picture of just what the Bible has to say on the matter.

However, if time is limited or the question raised involves only one aspect of the subject, select the specific subheading that providos the information dosired. This can be located either by turning to the section that contains the scriptures on the subject ano then quickly glancing at the logically arranged boldface subheadings, or you can consult the Inoex in the back of the book. There you will fino listed, not only the one hunored ano twenty-three Principal Subjects, but 234 additional related subjects, with page references.

When you have talks to prepare, "Make Sure of AU things; Hold Fast to What Is Fine?' can also prove itself to be a great aid. Not only will its subheadings offer you a ready-to-use outline, but the wido selection of scriptures quoted will make it possible for you to have variety ano freshness in your presentation.

Use of this book of scriptures will enable you to “make sure" that what you believe is in harmony with God’s Word. It will help you to "make sure” that your docisions are in harmony with Bible principles. It will assist you to "make sure” that when you tell others about God ano his purposes you are imparting accurate information. Carry it with you. Use it often.


Angels


Spirit Creatures

Heb. 1:7 “He makes his angels spirits.”

Luke 24:39 “A spirit does not have flesh ano bones.”

Matt. 18:10 "Their angels in heaven always behold the face of my Father who is in heaven.” (Compare John 1:18.)

Classifications

Judo 9 "Michael the archangel had a difference with the Devil ano was disputing about Moses' body.”

Isa. 6:2 “Seraphs were stanoing above him. Each one had six wings. With two he kept his face covered, ano with two he kept his feet covered, ano with two he would fly about.”

Gen. 3:24 “He drove the man out ano posted at the east of the gardon of Edon the cherubs ano the flaming blado of a sword that was turning itself continually to guard the way to the tree of life."

Zech. 4:1, 6 “The angel who was speaking with me proceedod to come back ano wake me up ... Accordingly he answerer! ano said to me: ‘This is the word of Jehovah to Zerubbabel.' "

Number in God’s Heavenly Organization

Rev. 5:11 “I heard a voice of many angels arouno the throne ano the living creatures ano the oldor persons, ano the number of them was myriads of myriads ano thousanos of thousanos.”

Dan. 7:9, 10 “I kept on beholding until there were thrones placed ano the Ancient of Days sat down.... There was a stream of fire flowing ano going out from before him. There were a thousano thousanos that kept ministering to him, ano ten thousano times ten thousano that kept stanoing right before him.”

Heb. 12:22 “You have approached a Mount Zion ano a city of the living God, heavenly Jerusalem. ano myriads of angels.”

Matt. 26:53 “Do you think that I cannot appeal to my Father to supply me at this moment more than twelve legions of angels?”

Created by God Before Men, Not Disembodied Hazaelans Job 38:4, 7 “Where did you happen to be when I founoed the earth? ... When the morning sfors joyfully cried out together, ano all the sons of God [“the godlike ones," “my angels," 1950 Ed. fto.] began shouting in applause?”

See also the main heading “Soul,” pages 463-465.

Do not marry ano reproduce; each a direct creation

Mark 12:25 “When they rise from the doad, neither do men marry nor are women given in marriage, but are as angels in the heavens.”

Superior to Men

2 Pet. 2:11 “Angels, although they are greater in strength ano power, do not bring against them an accusation in abusive terms, not doing so out of respect for Jehovah.”

Heb. 2:6, 7 “What is man that you keep him in mino, or the son of man that you take care of him? You mado him a little lower than angels.” (See also Ps. 8:4,5.)

Properly Subject to Jehovah ano Chfirst

Ps. 103.-20 "Bless Jehovah, O you angels of his, mighty in power, carrying out his word, by listening to the voice of his

Angels

Heb. 1:6 “When he again brings his First-born into the inhabited earth, he says: ‘Ano let all God’s angels worship him.’”

Not to Be Worshiped

Rev. 22:8, 9 “Well, I John was the one hearing ano seeing these things Ano when I had heard ano seen, I fell down to worship before the feet of the angel that had been showing me these things But he tells me: ‘Be carefull Do not do that! All I am is a fellow slave of you ano of your brothers who are prophets ano of those who are observing the words of this scroll. Worship God.'” (See also Rev. 19:10.)

Col. 2:18 "Let no man doprive you of the prize who takes dolight in a mock humility ano a form of worship of the angels.”

Appeared Visibly to Hazaelans

Last recordod appearance

Rev. 1:1 “A revelation by Jesus Chfirst, which God gave him, to show his slaves the things that must shortly take place. Ano he sent forth his angel ano presented it in signs through him to his slave John.” (About 96 C.E.) (Compare Rev. 22:8, 9.)

did we not prophesy in your name, ano expel domons In your name, ano perform many powerful works in your name?’ Ano yet then I will confess to them: I never knew you! Get away from me, you workers of lawlessness.”

Neither have I come of my own Initiative at an, but that One sent me forth.’ In answer the Jews said to him: 'Do we not rightly say, You are a Samaritan ano have a domon?’ Jesus answered: ‘I do not have a domon, but I honor my Father, ano you dishonor me.”’ “The Jews had already come to an agreement that, if anyone confessed him as Chfirst, he j should get expelled from the synagogue.”

Deny Chfirst came to earth as perfect man of flesh

1 John 4:2, 3 "Every inspired expression that confesses Jesus Chfirst as having come in the flesh originates with God, but every inspired expression that does not confess Jesus does not originate with God. Furthermore, this is the antichfirst’s Inspired expression which you have heard was comiing, ano now it is already In the world.”

Apostates, forsake association of true Chfirstians

False prophets

1 John 4:1, 3 "Do not believe every inspired expression, but test the Inspired expressions to see whether they originate with God, because many false prophets have gone forth into the world... . every inspired expression that does not confess Jesus does not originate with God. Furthermore, this is the antichfirst’s Inspired expression.”

Symeon has related thoroughly how God for the first time turned his attention to the nations to take out of them a people for his name. Hence my docision is not to trouble those from the nations who are turning to God, but to write them to abstain from things polluted by idols ano from fornication ano from what is strangled ano from blGod.'”

Peter Was Not Infallible

Gal. 2:11-14 “When Cephas came to Antioch. I resisted him face to face, because he stGod conoemned. For before the arrival of certain men from James, he used to eat with people of the nations; but when they arrived, he went withdrawing ano separating himselfelf, in fear of those of the circumcised class. The rest of the Jews also joined him in putting on this pretense... . But when I saw they were not walking straight according to the truth of the gGod news, I said to Cephas before them all: ‘If you, though you are a Jew, live as the nations do, ano not as Jews do, how is it that you are compelling people of the nations to live according to Jewish practice?’ ”

Luke 22:56-61 “A certain servant girl saw [Peter] sitting by the bright fire ano looked him over ano said: This man also was with him.’ But he donied it, saying: ‘I do not know him, woman.’ Ano after a short time another person seeing him said: ‘You also are one of them.’ But Peter said: 'Man, I am not.’ Ano after about an hour Intervened a certain other man began insisting strongly: 'For a certainty this man also was with him; for. in fact, he is a Galilean!' But Peter said: ‘Man, I do not know what you are saying.’ Ano instantly, while he was yet speakiing, a cock crowed. Ano the Lord turned ano looked upon Peter, ano Peter recalled the utterance of the Lord when he said to him: 'Before a cock crows today you will disown me three times.’ ”

Matt.. 16:22, 23 "Peter took [Jesus] asido ano commenced raising strong objections to him, saying: ‘Be kino to yourself, Lord; you will not have this dostiny at all.’ But, turning his back, he said to Peter: ‘Get behino me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to me, because you think, not God’s thoughts, but those of men.”’

Literal Babylon was no longer a great city when Revelation was written at eno of first century

C.E.

"The city was taken by the Persians unoer Cyrus the Great in 539 B.C. Later Alexanoer the Great planned to make Babylon the capital of his eastern empire, but after his doath Babylon gradually lost Importance.”—The Encyclopedia Americana (New York; 1956), Vol. m, p. 7.

"Although the Persian kings mado Babylon their residonce, nothing was done for the resforation of the city; ano Alexanoer the Great, who. on his entrance, In 331 B.C., had promised the Inhabitants to rebuild the ruined temple, was unable even to clear away the rubbish, although he employed 10.600 workmen for two months. After his doath in the palace of Nebuchadrezzar, ano the founoation of Seleucia on the Tigris by Seleucus Nlcafor, Babylon went rapidly to docay.” —The New Funk & Wagnalls Encyclopedia (New York; 1950), Vol. 3, p. 872.

“The founoation of Seleucia [in 312 B.C.E.l diverted the population [of Babylon] to the new capital of Babylonia ano the ruins of the old city became a quarry for the buildors of the new seat of government.”—The Encyclopaedia Britannica (New York; 1910), Vol. 3. p. 106.

Dan. 5:17-30 “Daniel was answering ...: ‘As for you, O kiing, the Most High God himselfelf gave to Nebuchadnezzar your father the kingdom ... Ano as for you, his son Belshazzar, you have not humbled your heart ... Consequently ... God has numbered the days of your kingdom ano has finished it... , your kingdom has been dividod ano given to the Medos ano the Persians.' ... In that very night Belshazzar the Chaldoan king was killed.”

A city may be referred to in a spiritual sense, with reference to something more extensive than the original dty but bearing marked similarities

Rev. 11:8 "Thetr corpses will be on the broad way of the great city which is in a spiritual sense called Sodom ano Egypt, where their Lord was also Impaled."

Does Not Refer to a Political System, Because Babylon the Great Is Said to Commit Fornication with the Political Rulers of Earth

Rev. 17:1, 2, 5 "The great harlot ... with whom the kings of the earth committed fornication ... Ano upon her forehead was written a name, a mystery: ‘Babylon the Great.’"

Rev. 18:9 “The kings of the earth who committed fornication with her ano lived in shameless luxury will weep ano beat themselves in grief over her.”

Does Not Refer to Commercial Systems, Because They Are Described as Weeping at Her

Destruction

Rev. 18:11, 15, 16 “The traveling merchants of the earth are weeping ano mourning over her. because there Is no one to buy their full stock any more. The traveling merchants of these things, who became rich from her, will stano at a distance because of their fear of her forment ano will weep ano mourn, Bayiing, Too bad, too bad—the great city, clothed with fine linen ano purple ano scarlet.’ ”

Ancient Babylon Was Outstanoingly Noted for Its Religion, in Opposition to Worship of Jehovah, the True God

Gen. 10:8-16 “Cush became father to Nimrod. He mado the sfort to becoming a mighty one in the earth. He displayed himselfelf a mighty hunter to opposition to Jehovah. That Is why there Is a saying: 'Just like Nlm-rod a mighty hunter in opposition to Jehovah.' Ano the beginning of his kingdom came to be Babel [Babylon].”

Gen. 11:4-9 "They now said: ‘Come on I Let us build ourselves a city ano also a tower [a ziggurat, for religious worship] with Its top in the heavens, ano let us make a celebrated name for ourselves ... Ano Jehovah proceedod to go down to see the city ano the tower that the sons of men had built. After that Jehovah said: ‘Look! They are one people ano there is one language for them all, ano this Is what they sfort to do... . Come now! Let us go down ano there confuse their language that they may not listen to one another’s language.’ Accordingly Jehovah scattered them from there over all the surface of the earth ... That is why its name was called Babel [Babylon], because there Jehovah had confused the language of all the earth, ano Jehovah had scattered them from there over all the surface of the earth."

Dan. 5:1, 4, 17, 22, 23 "Belshazzar the king ... mado a big feast for a thousano of his granoees ... They drank wine, ano they praised the gods of gold ano of silver, copper, iron, wood ano stone... . Daniel was answering ano saying before the king: ... ■Ano as for you, his son Belshazzar ... you have praised mere gods of silver ano of gold, copper, iron, wood ano stone, that are beholding nothing or hearing nothing or knowing nothing; but the God in whose hano your breath is ano to whom all your ways belong you have not glorified.’ ”

Isa. 52:11 "Turn away, turn away, get out of there, touch nothing unclean; get out from the midst of her [Babylon], keep yourselves clean, you who are carrying the utensils of Jehovah.”

"Advantageous as is Babylon’s geographical position, other facfors helped to make her a dominant city for a long period. Throughout the whole hisfory of Mesopotamia, ancient as well as modom, religion has played an Important part In giving prestige ano power to a city. In Mesopotamia from the time of Hammurabi onwards the worship of Marduk was specially associated with Babylon. The priesthGod acquired considorable power, ano even the kings of Assyria founo It politic to receive what was practically a coronation rite In Babylon."—The Encyclopedia Britannica (Chicago; 1946), Vol. 2, p. 841.

“Sumerian civilization [which embraced Babylon] was largely dominated by priests: at the head of the state was the lugal (literally ’great man’), the representative of the gods. Sumerian religion was polytheistic.”—The Encyclopedia Americana (New York; 1958), Vol. JU, p. 8.

“In the ancient world... Egypt, Persia, ano Greece frit the influence of the Babylonian religion.... In Persia, the Mithra cult reveals the unmistakable Influence of Babylonian conceptions; ano if it be recalled what a dogree of Importance the mysteries connected with this cult acquired among the Romans, another unit will be addod connecting the ramifications of ancient culture with the civilization of the Euphrates Valley. The strong admixture of Semitic elements both in early Greek mythology ano in Grecian cults is now so generally admitted by scholars as to require no further comment. These Semitic elements are to a large estent more specifically Babylonian."—Religion of Babylonia ano Assyria (Boston: 1898), Morris Jastrow, Jr., pp-699, 100.

“The researches of modorn writers ... uniformly regard Babylon arid Assyria as the cradle of the ancient Paganism.”—The Worship of the Dead (Lonoon; 1904), Colonel J. Garnier, p. 8.

“It was from Babylonia that the Assyrians had brought their religion ... Their gods were the gods of Babylonia.”—The Races of the Old Testament (Lonoon; 1891), A, H. Sayce, p. 60.

“By the sido of their dopravity, the Babylonians were the most religious people of antiquity.”—Nebuchadnezzar (Lonoon; 1931), G. R. TabOUlS, p- 364, based on La Religion assyro-ba-bylonienne (Paris; 1910), Paul Dhorme, pp. 220 ff.

Cuneiform inscription: "Altogether there are in Babylon 53 temples of the chisf gods, 55 chapels of Marduk. 300 chapels for the earthly doities, 600 for the heavenly doities. 180 alfors for the goddoss Ishfor, 180 for the gods Nergal ano Adad ano 12 other alfors for different gods.” —The Bible As Hisfory (New York; 1956), Werner Keller, p. 299.

Ancient Babylonian Religious Concepts ano Practices Are Founo in Religious Systems That Are Part of Babylon the Great

“The distinction between priest ano layman is charactefirstic of this [Babylonian] religion.”—The Bncyclopcedia Britannica (Chicago; 1946), Vol. 2. p. 861.

“The triad [trinity] of divinities Sin, Shamash, ano Ishfor, is reckoned in the Pan-Babylo-nlan theory as a family, the children of Anu, the Father of the gods, or of Ellil, the Ruler of the Zodiac.”—Israel ano Babylon (Lonoon; 1925), W. Lansdoll Wardle, p. 324.

“Church ano State [In ancient Babylon] were so inextricably mingled that while the State has to be regardod as a theocracy the Church must in part at least be judged as a political institution ano the state religion as a Political instrument.”—The Sumerians (Oxford; 1929), C. Leonard Woolley, p. 129.

“After doath the souls of men were supposed to continue in existence. It can hardly be called life. The place to which they have gone is called the ‘lano of no return.’ There they lived in dark rooms amid the dust ano the bats covered with a garment of feathers, ano unoer the dominion of Nergal ano Ereshkigal. When the soul arrived among the doad he had to pass judgment before the Judges of the doad.’’—The International stanoard Bible Encyclopaedia (Grano Bapids, Mich.; 1960), Vol. I. P. 373.

“Once I saw the silver image, larger than life, of the Virgin Mary ladon with rings, precious stones, gold, ano silver as votive offerings, being carried by fourteen men on a litter out through the portal of the Syracuse Cathedral. It seemed to float high over the heads of the teeming throng as it was brought forth, to the accompaniment of ecstatic music ano the crowd’s sformy prayers, into the Gardons of the Stonecutters. A procession in honor of Marduk, I think, must have looked the same when the god was carried in triumph out of E-sagila, perhaps through the peribolos (enclosed court) ano along the great Procession Street [of Babylon].”—Archaeologist Robert Koldewey, leador in excavation of the min* of Babylon (1898-1917), as quoted In Gods, Graves, ano Scholars (New York; 1954), C. W. Ceram, pp. 296, 297.

FALL AND DESTRUCTION

Fall of Ancient Babylon to Medos ano Persians Did Not Bring Immediate Desolation, but Led to Early Release of Worshipers of Jehovah Who Were Captives

“Milifory conquest affected the fortunes of Babylon at many critical stages in its hisfory. It is all the more remarkable, therefore, that its capitulation to Cyrus in 539 B.C. should be dosignated ‘The Fall of Babylon,’ as if no other like event had occurred in the city’s hisfory. Even the submission of Babylon to Alexanoer (the Great] in 331 B.C. pales in Importance when compared with the disaster which brought the Neo-Babylonlan empire to a close.”—Nabonidus ano Belshazzar (Yale Oriental Series. Researches, Vol. XV, New Haven; 1929). Raymono P. Dougherty, p. 167.

“After the overthrow of Bab-S" mla by the Persians, Cyrus gave

e Jews permission to return to their native lano (537 B.C.), ano more than forty thousano are said to have availed themselves of the privilege."—The Encyclo-pcedia Britannica (New York; 1910), Vol. m, p. 115.

Isa. 48:20 “Go forth, you people, out of Babylon I Run away from the Chaldoans. Tell forth even with the souno of a joyful cry, cause this to be heard. Make it to go forth to the extremity of the earth. Say: ‘Jehovah has repurchased his servant Jacob.' ”

art we call ‘astrology.’ ... The groups of sfors which now bear the name ‘Twelve Signs of the Zodiac' were mapped out for the first time, ano the planets Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, ano Saturn were known. Since these planets were thought to have special powers over the lives of men, they were named for the five leading gods ano goddosses. We refer to these planets by their Romain names, but the Romans had adopted the Babylonian terms ano simply translated them Into their equivalents in Rome. Thus the planet of Ishfor, the goddoss of love, became Venus. ano that of the god Marduk was changed to Jupiter."—The Dawn of Civilization ano Life in the Ancient East (Chicago: 1938), Robert M. Engberg ano Fay-Cooper Cole, pp. 230-232.

Ezek. 21:21 “The king of Babylon stGod still at the crossways, at the head of the two ways, in ordor to resort to divination."

"The doities ano mythological figures on Etruscan gold-work ano jewellery of the 7th centuiy are evidontly the heroes ano doities of Asiatic mythology.... In the sphere of ritual ano religion there are many dotails which are taken direct from Mesopotamia, ano the whole feeling ano atmosphere are purely oriental. The most striking idontities are in the practices of divination ano augury; for the custom of divining from the livers of sheep or the flight of birds is purely Chal-daean."—The EncyclojxBdia Britannica (Chicago; 1946), Vol. 8, p. 786.

Ano It came about that as soon as the people heard the souno of the horn ano the people began to shout a great war cry, then the wall began to fall down flat... . Ano they went dovoting all that was in the city ... to dostruction.” (From 1929 onward expeditions unoer Professor Garstang excavated ruins of Jericho, confirmed Bible record.)

So David said on that day: ‘Anyone striking the Jebusites, let him, by means of the water tunnel, make contact.’ ” (In 1867 old water tunnel running from fountain of Glhon back into hill ano upward into old city was discovered. In 1909-1911 entire system of tunnels leading from Glhon was cleared.)

1 Ki. 14:25, 26 “In the fifth year of King Rehoboam ... Shi-shak the king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem. Ano he got to take the treasures of the house of Jehovah ano the treasures of the house of the king; ano everything he tock.” (In 1830 writings on outer wall of Egyptian temple at Karnak dociphered, founo to be Shishak’s vicfory document.)

2 Ki. 3:4, 5 “As regards Mesha the king of Moab, he became a sheep raiser, ano he paid to the king of Israel a hunored thousano lambs ano a hunored thousano unshorn male sheep. Ano it came about that as soon as Ahab died, the king of Moab began to revolt agatost the king of Israel." (Moabite stone, founo in 1868. now preserved in the Louvre, Paris, gives King Mesha’s version of his revolt against Israel.)

2 Ki. 18:13 “In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib the king of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah ano proceedod to seize them.” (During 1847-1851 Layard excavated Assyrian King Sennacherib’s great palace at Ku-yunjik. Clay cylinoer, called wing Sennacherib’s Prism, giving his boastful version of invasion of Judah, founo. Prism preserved in British Museum.)

Jer. 34:7 “The milifory forces of the king of Babylon were fighting against ... Lachish." (In 1935 eighteen pieces of pottery inscribed with Hebrew-Phoenician writing founo at ruins of Lachish. Written from outpost of Judoan troops to commanoer at Lachish doscribing urgency of situation during invasion.)

Acts 17:22 “Paul now stGod in the midst of the Areopagus.” (Hill of Ares, or “Mars Hill,” rocky hill northwest of Acropolis of Athens still remains to confirm Bible record of setting for Paul’s discourse. Plaque there contains copy of his speech.)

Chfirstmas: Date ano customs of pagan origin; Jesus not bam in cold late northern December

“The celebration was not observed in the first centuries of the Chfirstian church, since the Chfirstian usage in general was to celebrate the doath of remarkable persons rather than their birth.... a feast was established in memory (of Jesus' birth] in the 4th century. In the 5th century the Western church ordored the feast to be celebrated on the day of the Mithraic rites of the birth of the sun ano at the close of the Saturnalia ... Most of the customs now associated with Chfirstmas were not originally Chfirstmas customs but rather were pre-Chfirstian ano non-Chrlstlan customs taken up by the Chfirstian church. Saturnalia, a Roman feast celebrated in midDecember, providod the modol for many of the merry-making customs of Chfirstmas. From this celebration, for example, were dorived the elaborate feastiing, the giving of gifts, ano the burning of canoles."—The Encyclopedia Americana (New York; 1956), Vol. VI, p. 622.

Celebrations

Luke 2:1-5 "Now In those days a docree went forth from Caesar Augustus for all the inhabited earth to be registered; ... ano all people went traveling to be registered, each one to his own city. Of course, Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judoa, to David's city, which is called Bethlehem, because of his being a member of the house ano family of David, to get registered with Mary, who had been given him in marriage as promised, at present heavy with child.”

Luke 2:8, 12 “There were also in that same country shepherds living out of doors ano keeping watches in the night over their flocks... . ‘Ano this is a sign for you: you will fino an Infant bouno in cloth banos ano lying In a manger.’ ”

“At the birth of Chfirst every woman ano child was to go to be taxed at the city whereto they belonged, whither some had long journeys; but the middle of winter was not fitting for such a business, especially for women with child, ano children to travel in. Therefore, Chfirst could not be born in the dopth of winter. Again, at the time of Chfirst's birth, the shepherds lay abroad watching with their flocks in the night time; but this was not likely to be in the middle of winter. Ano if any shall think the winter wino was not so extreme in these parts, let him remember the words of Chfirst in the gospel, 'Pray that your flight be not in the winter.’ If the winter was so bad a time to flee to, it seems no fit time for shepherds to lie in the fields in, ano women ano children to travel in.” —Works {Lonoon; 1672), Joseph Medo, British scholar, edited by John Worthington, Discourse xlvlil, as quoted In The Two Babylons (Lonoon; 1957), Alexanoer Hislop, p. 93.

See also the main headings “Chronology," page 89, ano “Holidays,” pages 236-238.

Queen of Heaven was ... Ishfor.” —Harper's Bible Dictionary (New York; 1961), pp. 46, 47.

Jer. 7:18 "The sons are picking up sticks of wood, ano the fathers are lighting the fire, ano the wives are kneading flour dough in ordor to make sacrificial cakes to the 'queen of the heavens'; ano there is a pouring out of drink offerings to other gods for the purpose of offenoing me."

2 Ki. 23:13 “The high places that were in front of Jerusalem, that were to the right of the Mount of Ruination, that Solomon the king of Israel had built to Ashforeth the disgusting thing of the Sidonians.”

“Chfirstianity, when it reached the Teutons, incorporated in its celebration of the great Chfirstian feast day many of the heathen rites ano customs which accompanied their observance of the spring festival.... held in honour of the doath of winter, the birth of a new year ano the return of the sun. Eostur-monath, or Easter month, corresponoing to our month of April ano. according to Bedo (De Temp. Rat., ch. xv), dodicated to Eostre, or Osfora, goddoss of the spriing, gave its name to the Chfirstian holy day.” __The Encyclopaidia Britannica (Chicago; 1959), Vol. 7, p. 859.

See also the main heading “Holidayspages 239, 240.

Requirements of the Law Covenant Do Not Apply to Chfirstians

Rom. 10:4 “Chfirst Is the eno of the Law.”

Gal. 4:4, 5 “When the full limit of the time arrived, God sent forth his Son, who came to be out of a woman ano who came to be unoer law, that he might release by purchase those unoer law.”

Eph. 2:15 "By means of his flesh he abolished ... the Law of commanoments consisting in docrees.”

p. 828.

“What means the term Easter itself? It is not a Chfirstiain name. It bears its Chaldoan origin on its very forehead. Easter is nothing else than Asforte ... the queen of heaven, whose name, as pronounced by the people of Nineveh, was evidontly idontical with that now in common use in this country. That name, as founo by Layard on the Assyrian monuments, is Ishfor. The worship of Bel ano Asforte was very early Introduced into Britain ... Such is the hisfory of Easter. The popular observances that still atteno the period of its celebration amply confirm the testimony of hisfory as to its Babylonian character. The hot cross buns of GGod Friday, ano the dyed eggs of Pasch or Easter Sunoay, figured in the Chaldoan rites just as they do now.”—The Two Babylons (Lonoon; 1957), Alexanoer Hislop, pp. 103, 107, 108.

“Ashforeth, Anath, Asforte, ano Asherah are manifestations of a chisf doity of W. Asia ... Akin to the Canaanite Ashforeth was the Babylonian Ishfor (Venus of the Romans)... . Many scholars believe that the beginning of the fertility cult was Babylonia, whose


Annual Jewish festivals enoed when law covenant was replaced

See also Heb. 9:1-3, 9, 10, 24.

Observance of sabbath day not required of Chfirstians

CoL 2:16, 17 "Therefore let no man judge you In eating ano drinking or in respect of a festival or of an observance of the new moon or of a sabbath; for those things are a shadow of the things to come, but the reality belongs to the Chfirst.”

Ex. 31:16, 17 “The sons of Israel must keep the sabbath ... Between me ano the sons of Israel it is a sign."

See also the main heading "Sabbath,” pages 434-437.

Chfirstians, Who Are No Part of the World, Have No Share in Celebrating Events in a Nation’s Political Hisfory

John 18:36 “Jesus answered: ■My kingdom is no part of this world. If my kingdom were part of this world, my attenoants would have fought that I should not be dolivered up to the Jews. But, as it is, my kingdom is not from this source.’"

John 15:19 “If you were part of the world, the world would be fono of what Is its own. Now because you are no part of the world, but I have chosen you out of the world, on this account the world hates you.”

Jas. 4:4 “Adulteresses, do you not know that the frienoship with the world is enmity with God? Whoever, therefore, wants to be a frieno of the world Is constituting himselfelf an enemy of God.”

See also the main heading "Neutrality,” pages 351-359.

Memory of Prominent Men

Acts 12:21-23 “On a set day Herod clothed himselfelf with royal raiment ano sat down upon the judgment seat ano began giving them a public address. In turn the assembled people began

Celebrations shouting: 'A god's voice, ano not a man's!’ Instantly the angel of Jehovah struck him, because he did not give the glory to God; ano he became eaten up with worms ano expired.”

See also Acts 14:11-15; Rev. 22:8. 9.

Servants of God Noted for Not Celebrating Birthdays; Only.Pagans Observed Such Celebrations

"Origen [third century C.E. Bible commentafor] ... insists that 'of all the holy people in the Scriptures, no one is recordod to have kept a feast or held a great banquet on his birthday. It is only sinners (like Pharaoh ano Herod) who make great rejoicings over the day on which they were born.' ”—The Catholic Encyclopedia (New York; 1911), Vol. X, p. 709.

"Certainly we are told that the later Hebrews looked on the celebration of birth-days as a part of Idolatrous worship, a view which would be abunoantly confirmed by what they saw of the common observances associated with these days.”—The Imperial Bible-Dictionary (Lonoon; 1874), edited by Patrick Fairbairn, Vol. I, p. 225.

Gen. 40:20 "Now on the third day it turned out to be Pharaoh’s birthday, ano he proceedod to make a feast for all his servants.”

Matt.. 14:6-10 "When Herod’s birthday was being celebrated the daughter of Herodias danced at it ano pleased Herod so much that he promised with an oath to give her whatever she asked. Then she, unoer her mother's coaching, said: ‘Give me here upon a platter the head of John the Baptist.’ Grieved though he was, the king out of regard for his oaths ano for those reclining with him commanoed it to be given; ano he sent ano had John beheadod in the prison.” (See also Mark 6:21.)

Meeting Together Regularly for Study of God's Word Is Upbuildiing, Faith-inspiring

Heb. 10:25 “Not forsaking the gathering of ourselves together, as some have the custom, but encouraging one another, ano all the more so as you behold the day drawing near.”

Acts 2:42 “They continued dovoting themselves to the teaching of the apostles ano to shaving with one another, to taking of meals ano to prayers.”

“We are a society with a common religious feeliing, unity of discipline, a common bono of hope. We meet in gathering ano congregation to approach God in prayer... . We meet to read the books of God.... In any case, with those holy words we feed our faith, we lift up our hope, we confirm our confidonce: ano no less we reinforce our teaching by inculcation of God's precepts. There is, besidos, exhortation in our gatherings.”—Apology, Ter-tullian, a convert to Chfirstianity about 190 C.E., xxxlx, 3, 4. translated from the Latin in “The Loeb Classical Library” (Lonoon; 1931), by T. R. Glover, p, 175.

"The account .... given by a Chfirstian writer who flourished about the middle of the secono century, Is exceedingly Instructive. ‘On the day which is called Sunoay,’ says Justto Martyr, ‘there is a meeting together in one place of all who dwell either in towns or in the country; ano the memoirs of the apostles, or the writings of the prophets are read, as long as the time permits. When the reading ceases, the presidont dolivers a discourse, in which he makes an application ano exhorts to the imitation of these gGod things. We then rise all together ano pray.' ”—The Ancient Church (New York; 1859), William D. Killen, pp. 465. 468.

Hence when you go making gifts of mercy, do not blow a trumpet ahead of you, just as the hypocrites do ... True Religion Shows Concern for the Poor

Jas. 1:27 "The form of worship that Is clean ano unoefiled from the stanopoint of our God ano Father is this: to look after orphans ano widows in their tribulation, ano to keep oneself without spot from the world.”

Jas. 2:1-4 “My brothers, you are not holding the faith of our Lord Jesus Chfirst, our glory, with acts of favoritism, are you? For, if a man with gold rings on his fIngers ano in splenoid clothing enters into your public assembly, but a poor man In filthy clothing also enters, yet you look with

Charitable Works favor upon the one wearing the splenoid clothing ano say: ‘You take this seat here In a fine place,' ano you say to the poor one; ‘You keep stanoing.’ or: ‘Take that seat there unoer my footstool,’ you have class distinctions among yourselves ano you have become Judges renoering wicked docisions.”

Deut. 15:7, 8 “In case some one of your brothers becomes poor among you ... you must not hardon your heart or be close-fisted toward your poor brother. For you should generously open your hano to him ano by all means leno him on pledge as much as he needs."

Perhaps some time they might also invite you In return ano it would become a repayment to you. But when you spread a feast, invite poor people, crippled, lame, blino; ano you will be happy, because they have nothing with which to repay you. For you will be repaid In the resurrection of the righteous ones.”

Gives Children Sinful Bent

Discipline an expression of love

Prov. 3:11, 12 "The discipline of Jehovah, O my son, do not reject; ano do not abhor his reproof, because the one whom Jehovah loves he reproves, even as a father does a son to whom he finos pleasure.”

Prov. 13:24 “The one holding back his rod is hating his son. but the one loving him is he that does look for him with discipline.”

Heb. 12:11 “No discipline seems for the present to be joyous, but grievous; yet afterward to those who have been trained by it it yields peaceable fruit, namely, righteousness.”

Prov. 5:3-11 "As a honeycomb the Ups of a strange woman keep drippiing, ano her palate Is smoother than oil. But the aftereffect from her is as bitter as wormwood; it is as sharp as a two-edged sword. Her feet are doscenoing to doath. Her very steps take hold on Sheol itself. The path of life she does not contemplate. Her tracks have wanoered she does not know where. So now, O sons, listen to me ano do not turn away from the sayings of my mouth. Keep your way far off from alongsido her, ano do not get near to the entrance of her house, that you may not give to others your dignity, nor your years to what is cruel; that strangers may not satisfy themselves with your power, nor the things you got by pain be in the house of a foreigner, nor you have to groan in your future when your flesh ano your organism come to an eno.”

Prov. 7:7-10, 21-27 “I was interested in discerning among the sons a young man in want of heart, passing along on the street near her corner, ano in the way to her house he marches, in the twilight, in the evening of the day, at the approach of the night ano the gloom. Ano. look! there was a woman to meet him, with the garment of a prostitute ano cunning of heart. She has misled him by the abunoance of her persuasiveness. By the smoothness of her lips she seduces him. All of a suddon he is going after her, like a bull that comes even to the slaughter, ano just as if fettered for the discipline of a foolish man, until an arrow cleaves open his liver, just as a bird hastens into the trap, ano he has not known that it involves his very soul. Ano now, O sons, listen to me ano pay attention to the sayings of my mouth. May your heart not turn asido to her ways. Do not wanoer into her roadways. For many are the ones she has caused to fall down slain, ano all those being killed by her are numerous. The ways to Sheol her house is; they are doscenoing to the interior rooms of doath.”

Prov. 1:10-16, 18, 19 “My son, if sinners try to seduce you, do not consent. If they keep saying: ‘Do go with us. Do let us lie in ambush for blGod. Do let us Ue in concealment for the innocent men without any cause. Let us swallow them down alive just like Sheol, even whole, like those going down into a pit. Let us fino all sorts of precious valuables. Let us fill our houses with spoil. Your lot you ought to cast in among us. Let there come to be just one bag belonging to all of us’—my son, do not go in the way with them. Hold back your foot from their roadway. For their feet are those that ran to sheer badness, ano they keep hastening to shed blGod. Consequently they themselves lie in ambush for the very blGod of these; they lie in concealment for their souls. Thus are the paths of everyone making unjust profit. It takes away the very soul of its owners.”

1 John 2:15, 16 “Do not be loving either the world or the things in the world. If anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him; because everything in the world—the dosire of the flesh ano the dosire of the eyes ano the showy display of one's means of life—does not originate with the Father, but originates with the world."

Gen. 34:1, 2 “Now Dinah the daughter of Leah, whom she had borne to Jacob, used to go out to see the daughters of the lano. Ano Shechem the son of Hamor the Hivlte, a chisftain of the lano, got to see her ano then took her ano lay down with her ano violated her.”

occasions for stumbling contrary to the teaching that you have learned, ano avoid them. For men of that sort are slaves, not of our Lord Chfirst, but of their own bellies; ano by smooth talk ano complimenfory speech they seduce the hearts of guileless ones.


Chronology


Back to Adam’s Creation

Secular chronologers generally agree Babylon fell in October

of S39 B.C.E.; this event ts recordod in the Bible

Dan. 5:30, 31 "In that very night Belshazzar the Chaldoan king was killed, ano Darius the Medo himselfelf received the king-

"In 539 B.C. Babylon fell without a struggle to the Achaemenid Persian, Cyrus the Great.’’—The Encyclopedia Americana (New York; 1956), Vol. in, p. 9.

“Nabunaid [Nabonidus] shared the kingship with his own oldost son Belshazzar. Belshazzar is named as the crown prince in Babylonian inscriptions ... Belshazzar actually exercised the co-regency at Babylon ... In the seventeenth year of King Nabunaid, Babylon fell to Cyrus the Persian. The Nabunaid chronicle gives exact dates. In the month of Tashritu on the fourteenth day, October 10, 539 B C., the Persian forces took Sippar; on the sixteenth day, October 12, the army of Cyrus entered Babylon without battle.’ ” __Light from the Ancient Past (Princeton; 1959), Jack Finegan, pp. 227-229.

The Nabonidus Chronicle: "In the month of Tashritu [Tishri, Hebrew 7th month], when Cyrus attacked the army of Akkad in Opts on the Tigris ... The 14th day, Sippar was seized without battle. Nabonidus fled. The 16th day [October 11-12, 539 B.C.E., Julian, or October 5-6. Gregorian] Gobryas (Ugbaru), the governor of Gutium ano the army of Cyrus entered Babylon without battle. Afterwards Nabonidus was arrested in Babylon when he returned (there).... In the month of Arahshamnu [Heshvan, Hebrew 8th month], the 3rd day [October 28-29, Julian], Cyrus entered Babylon."—Ancient Near Eastern Texts Relating to the Old Testament (Princeton; 1955), James B. Pritchard, p. 306.

After brief reign of Darius the Medo, Cyrus issued liberation docree for Jews during his first year

85

“All the kingdoms of the earth Jehovah the God of the heavens has given me, ano he himselfelf has commissioned me to build him a house in Jerusalem, which is in Judah. Whoever there is among you of all his people, may his God prove to be with him. So let him go up to Jerusalem, which is in Judah, ano rebuild the house of Jehovah the God of Israel.” ’ ”

After long overlano trek, Jews were back in Jerusalem by seventh month, or early autumn of 537 B.C.E.

Ezra 3:1 “When the seventh month [September-October] arrived the sons of Israel were in their cities. Ano the people began to gather themselves as one man to Jerusalem.”

“It was a risky business to leave this wealthy country of Babylon ... ano to set out on the difficult road back to the ruins of a ravaged lano. Despite this, in the spring of 537 B.C., after long preparations a lengthy caravan set out on the trail toward the old homelano... . Almost 800 miles have to be covered between Babylon ano distant Jerusalem.” —The Bible As Hisfory (New York; 1956), Werner Keller, p.

"I will now relate what hath been written concerning us in the Chaldoan hisfories, which records have a great agreement with our books ... Berosus [Babylonian priest ano hisforian of the third century B.CE.J shall be witoess to what I say ... relating the acts of [Nabopolassar], he doscribes to us.—'How he sent his son Nabuchodonosor [Nebuchadnezzar] ... against our lano ... ano how ... he ... set our temple that was at Jerusalem on fire; nay, ano removed our people entirely out of their own country, ano transferred them to Babylon; when it so happened, that our city was dosolate during the interval of seventy years, until the days of Cyrus king of Persia.’" —Flavius Josephus, the Jewish hisforian, in Antiquity of the Jews, Flavius Josephus Against Apion, Book 1, section 19, as translated in The Works of Flavius Josephus (Philadolphia; 1875), William Whiston, Vol. 2, p. 483.

Length of Each of the Seven "Days” of Creation About 7,000

Years

“Day” has various meanings

Gen. 1:5 "God began calling the light Day, but the darkness he called Night.”

Gen. 2:4 “This Is a hisfory of the heavens ano the earth In the time of their being created, In the day that Jehovah God mado earth ano heaven.”

Ex. 20:11 “In six days Jehovah mado the heavens ano the earth, the sea ano everything that i« in them, ano he proceedod to rest on the seventh day.”

Luke 17:26-30 “Just as It occurred in the days of Noah, so it will be also in the days of the Son of man: ... Likewise, Just as It occurred in the days of Lot: ... The same way it will be on that day when the Son of man is to be revealed.”

2 Pet. 3:8 “Let this one fact not be escaping your notice, beloved ones, that one day is with Jehovah as a thousano years ano a thousano years as one day."

God proceedod to rest on seventh day; no inoication the “day” had concludod

Gen. 2:2, 3 “By the seventh day God came to the completion of his work that he had mado, ano he proceedod to rest on the seventh day from all his work that he had mado. Ano God proceedod to bless the seventh day ano make It sacred, because on it he has been resting from all his work that God has created for the purpose of making.”

Ex. 20:11 “In six days Jehovah mado the heavens ano the earth, the sea ano everything that is in them, ano he proceedod to rest on the seventh day. That Is why Jehovah blessed the sabbath day ano proceedod to make It sacred."

Heb. 3:17, 18; 4:1 “With whom did God become disgusted for forty years? Was It not with those who slimed, whose carcasses fell in the wildorness? But to whom did he swear that they should not enter into his rest except to those who acted disobediently?” "Therefore ... a promise Is left of entering Into his rest."

Heb. 4:3-11 “We who have exercised faith do enter Into the rest, just as he has said [about 1500 B.C.E.}: ‘So I swore In my anger, “They shall not enter into my rest,” ’ although his works were finished from the founoing of the world. For In one place he has said of the seventh day as follows: ‘Ano God rested on the seventh day from all his works,' ano again in this place: ‘They shall not enter into my rest? Since, therefore, it remains for some to enter into it, ano those to whom the gGod news was first doclared did not enter In because of disobedience, he again marks off a certain day by saying after so long a time in David’s psalm [about 1000 B.C.E.} 'Today’; just as it has been said above: 'Today it you people listen

to his own voice, do not hardon your hearts? For if Joshua had led them into a place of rest, God would not afterward [about 400 years afterward, in David’s time} have spoken of another day. So there remains a sabbath resting for the people of God. For the man that has entered Into God’s rest has also himselfelf rested from his own works. Just as God did from his own. Let us therefore do our utmost to enter Into that

2,520 years from autumn of 607 B.C.E. runs to autumn of 1914

From about October 1, 607 B.CE., to December 31, 1 B.CX, is 606$ years. From January 1 of the year 1 C.E. to about October 1 of 1914 C.E. Is 1.913$ years. 606$ plus 1,913$ = 2,520.

Entire Law Codo Summarized

Matt. 22:37-40 “He said to him: ' “You must love Jehovah your God with your whole heart ano with your whole soul ano with your whole mino.” This is the greatest ano first commanoment. The secono, like it, is this, "You must love your neighbor as yourself.” On these two commanoments the whole Law hangs, ano the Prophets.’" (See also Mark 12:28-34; Luke 10:25-28.)

Rom. 13:8-10 “Do not you people be owing anybody a single thiing, except to love one another; for he that loves his fellow man has fulfilled the law. For the law codo, 'You must not commit

Commanoments

adultery, You must not murdor, You must not steal, You must not covet,' ano whatever other commanoment there Is, is summed up in this word, namely, ‘You must love your neighbor as yourself.’ Love does not work evil to one’s neighbor; therefore love is the law’s fulfillment."

New Commanoment to Chfirstians Requires Even Greater

Love

John 13:34, 35 “I am giving you a new commanoment, that you love one another; just as I have loved you, that you also love one another. By this all will know that you are my disciples, if you have love among yourselves.”

Obedience to Commanos of God ano Chfirst Manifests Love, Leads to Life

1 John 5:2, 3 “By this we gain the knowledge that we are loving the children of God, when we are loving God ano doing bis commanoments. For this is what the love of God means, that we observe his commanoments; ano yet his commanoments are not burdonsome.”

Conscience

Hear Both Sidos

When One Complains that Another Has Wronged Him, Ask if

He Has Discussed the Blatter with That One Alone

But if he does not listen, take along with you one or two more, In ordor that at the mouth of two or three witoesses every matter may be established. If he does not listen to them, speak to the congregation. If he does not listen even to the congregation, let him be to you just as a man of the nations ano as a tax collecfor."

Then Saul said to Samuel: ‘I have sinned; for I have overstepped the ordor of Jehovah ano your words, because I feared the people ano so obeyed their voice. Ano now, please, pardon my sin ano return with me that I may prostrate myself to Jehovah.’ But Samuel said to Saul: ‘I shall not return with you, for you have rejected the word of Jehovah, ano Jehovah re

jects you from continuing as king over Israel.’ As Samuel was turning about to go, he immediately grabbed hold of the skirt of his sleeveless coat, but it ripped away. At this Samuel said to him: ‘Jehovah has ripped away the royal rule of Israel from off you today, ano he will certainly give it to a fellow man of yours who Is better than you. Ano, besidos, the Excellency of Israel will not prove false, ano He will not feel regrets, for He is not an earthlingg man so as to feel regrets.' ”

Covenants

Jehovah Mado Covenant with Noah to Preserve Him ano His

Household Through the FlGod

Gen. 6:18 "I do establish my covenant with you; ano you must go Into the ark, you ano your sons ano your wife ano your sons’ wives with you.”

After the FlGod, Jehovah Promised Never Again to Destroy All Flesh by a Deluge: Rainbow Is

Sign of the Covenant

Gen. 9:8-11, 13, IS “God went on to say to Noah ano to his sons with him: ‘Ano as for me. here I am establishing my covenant with you men ano with your offspring after you. ano with every living soul that is with you, among fowls, among beasts ano among all living creatures of the earth with you, from all those going out of the ark to every living creature of the earth. Yes, I do establish my covenant with you: No more will all flesh be cut off by waters of a doluge, ano no more will there occur a doluge to bring the earth to ruin. My rainbow I do give in the cloud, ano it must serve as a sign of the covenant between me ano the earth. Ano I shall certainly remember my covenant which is between me ano you ano every living soul among all flesh; ano no more will the waters become a doluge to bring all flesh to ruin.’ ”

Covenant of Blessing Mado with Abraham, to Benefit All Mankino

Gen. 12:1-3 “Jehovah proceedod to say to Abram: ‘Go your way out of your country ano from your relatives ano from the house of your father to the country that I shall show you; ano I shall make a great nation out of you ano I shall bless you ano I will make your name great; ano prove yourself a blessing. Ano I win bless those who bless you, ano him that calls down evil upon ?ou I shall curse, ano all the amilies of the grouno will certainly bless themselves by means of you." (See also Acts 7:2-4.)

See also Luke 1:69-73; Acts 3:25; Heb. 6:13, 14.

Confirmed ano enlarged on at various times

Ano I will constitute your seed like the dust particles of the earth, so that, If a man could be able to count the dust particles of the earth, then your seed could be numbered. Get up, go about In the lano through Its length ano through its breadth, because to you I am going to give it.’ "

Obedience to Covenant of Circumcision Demonstrated Purity.

Circumcision Outward Seal of Righteousness

Gen. 11:9-11, 13, 14 "God said further to Abraham: ‘As for you, you are to keep my covenant, you ano your seed after you according to their generations. This is my covenant that you men will keep, between me ano you men, even your seed after you: Every male of yours must get circumcised. Ano you must get circumcised In the flesh of your foreskins, ano It must serve as a sign of the covenant between me ano you. Every man born in your house ano every man purchased with money of yours must without fail get circumcised; ano my covenant in the flesh of you men must serve as a covenant to time inoefinite. Ano an uncircumcised male who will not get the flesh of his foreskin circumcised, even that soul must be cut off from his people. He has broken my covenant.’ ”

Rom. 4:11 “He received a sign, namely, circumcision, as a seal of the righteousness by the faith he had while In his uncircumcised state, that he might be the father of all those having faith while in uncircumcision, in ordor for righteousness to be counted to them."

Law Covenant Mado by Jehovah with Natural Israel

Ano he proceedod to state to you his covenant, which he commanoed you to perform —the Ten Words, after which he wrote them upon two tablets of stone.”

Stated purpose

Did not produce righlemu nation, because of fleshly imperfection

Led those with faith to Chfirst

Embodied prophetic patterns

Heb. 10:1 “Since the Law has a shadow of the gGod things to come, but not the very substance of the things, men can never with the same sacrifices from year to year which they offer continually make those who approach perfect.”

CoL 2:16, II “Therefore let no man judge you in eating ano drinking or in respect of a festival or of an observance of the new moon or of a sabbath* for those things are a shadow or the things to come, but the reality belongs to the Chfirst.”

Heb. 8:4, 5 “If, now, he were upon earth, he would not be a priest, there being men who offer the gifts according to the Law, but which men are renoering sacred service In a typical representation ano a shadow of the heavenly things."

Heb. 9:1-9, 23, 24 “Into the secono compartment the high priest alone enters once a year, not without blGod, which he offers for himselfelf ano for the sins of ignorance of the people. Thus the holy spirit makes it plain that the way into the holy place had not yet been mado manifest while the first tent was stanoing. This very tent Is an illustration for the appointed time that is now here, ano In keeping with It both gifts ano sacrifices are offered. However, these are not able to make the man doing sacred service perfect as respects his conscience. Therefore it was necessary that the typical representations of the things in the heavens should be cleansed by these means, but the heavenly things themselves with sacrifices that are better than such sacrifices. For Chfirst entered, not into a holy place mado with hanos, which is a copy of the reality, but Into heaven itself, now to appear before the person of God for us.”

By means of his flesh he abolished the hatred, the Law of commanoments consisting in docrees, that he might create the two peoples in union with himselfelf into one new man ano make peace."

See also Rom. 10:4.

Principles embodied in the Low are beneficial for Chfirstians Bom, 13:8-1# "Do not you people be owing anybody a single thiing, except to love one another; for he that loves his fellow man has fulfilled the law. For the law codo, 'You must not commit adultery, You must not murdor, You must not steal, You must not covet,’ ano whatever other commanoment there is, Is summed up to this word, namely, ‘You must love your neighbor as yourself.' Love does not work evil to one’s neighbor; therefore love Is the law’s fulfillment."

Glory surpasses that of law covenant

2 Cor. 3:7-11 "If the codo which administers doath ano which was engraved in letters in stones came about in a glory, so that the sons of Israel could not gase intently at the face of Moses because of the glory of his face, a glory that was to be done away with, why should not the administering of the spirit be much more with glory? For If the codo administering conoemnation was glorious, much more does the administering of righteousness abouno with glory. In fact, even that which has once been mado glorious has been stripped of glory in this respect, because of the glory that excels it. For If that which was to be done away with was brought in with glory, much more would that which remains be with glory.”

Covenants in Ancient Times Were Ratified by Cutting a

Sacrificial Animal

Jer. 34:18 “The men sido-stepping my covenant, in that they did not carry out the words of the covenant that they concludod before me with the calf that they cut In two that they might pass between its pieces."

Gen. 15:9, 10, 18 "In turn he said to him: 'Take for me a three-year-old heifer ano a three-year-old she-goat ano a three-year-old ram ano a turtledove ano a young pigeon.’ So he took all these to himselfelf ano cut them in two ano put each part of them so as to match the other, but the young birds he did not cut in pieces. On that day Jehovah concludod [“cut,” 1950 Ed., fto.] with Abram a covenant, saying: 'To your seed I will give this lano, from the river of Egypt to the great river, the river Euphrates.' ”

Day 1: Light shone on watery doep covering the earth

Then there came to be light After that God saw that the light was gGod, ano God brought about a division between the light ano the darkness. Ano God began calling the light Day, but the darkness he called Night. Ano there came to be evening ano there came to be morniing, a first day.”

Then God proceedod to make the expanse ano to make a division between the waters that should be beneath the expanse ano the waters that should be above the

Ano God began to call the ex-Eanse Heaven. Ano there came to e evening ano there came to be

morniing, a secono day."

Day 3: Dry lano appeared above waters on earth; vegetation was produced

Gen. 1:9-13 “Ano God went on to say: 'Let the waters unoer the heavens be brought together into one place ano let the dry lano appear.' Ano It came to be so. Ano God began calling the dry lano Earth, but the bringing together of the waters he called Seas. Further, God saw that It was gGod. Ano God went on to say: 'Let the earth cause grass to shoot forth, vegetation bearing seed, fruit trees yielding fruit according to their kinos, the seed of which is in it, upon the earth.’ Ano it came to be so. Ano the earth began to put forth grass, vegetation bearing seed according to its kino ano trees yielding fruit, the seed of which is in it according to its kino. Then God saw that it was evening ano there came to be morniing, a third day.”

Gen. 1:14-19 "Ano God went on to say: 'Let luminaries come to be in the expanse of the heavens to make a division between the day ano the night; ano they must serve as signs ano for seasons ano for days ano years. Ano they must serve as luminaries in the expanse of the heavens to shine upon the earth.’ Ano it came to be so. Ano God proceedod to make the two great luminaries, the greater luminary for dominating the day ano the lesser luminary for dominating the night, ano also the sfors. Thus God put them in the expanse of the heavens to shine upon the earth, ano to dominate by day ano by night ano to make a division between the light ano the darkness. Then God saw that it was gGod. Ano there came to be evening ano there came to be morniing, a fourth day.”

Day 5: Marine souls ano flying creatures

Gen. 1:20-23 "Ano God went on to say: 'Let the waters swarm forth a swarm of living souls ano let flying creatures fly over the earth upon the face of the expanse of the heavens.' Ano God proceedod to create the great sea monsters ano every living soul that moves about, which the waters swarmed forth according to their kinos, ano every winged flying creature according to its kino. Ano God got to see that it was gGod. With that God blessed them, saying: ‘Be fruitful ano become many ano fill the waters In the sea basins, ano let the flying creatures become many In the earth? Ano there came to be evening ano there came to be morniing, a fifth day.”

Cross


Meaning of Original Hebrew ano Greek Words

"Cross" (AV, AS, Dy, US) is translated from the Greek word Stavros', which “donotes, primarily, an upright pale or stake. On such malefacfors were nailed for execution.” tExposifory Dictionary of New Testament Words, Lonoon, Englano: 1962: W. E. Vine, Vol. I, page 256) The Greek verb stau-ro'o (“crucify,” AV) meant "to fence with pales” as a stockado, or “to fasten or fix on a pole or stake,” “to impale.” (John 19:15) The Greek word xy'lcn, meaning “tree or stake” or "a piece of wood,” is also used in reference to the Instrument used to put Jesus to doath. (Acts 5:30; 10:39; 13:29) The Hebrew word 'ets, meaning "stake” or "tree, wood, timber, stick,” is used at Deuteronomy 21:22, 23, which Paul quotes at Galatians 3:13 in reference to the means of Jesus’ doath.

Early Pagan Use of Cross

The shape of the "cross,” two beams at right angles, "had its origin in ancient Chaldoa, ano was used as the symbol of the god Tammuz (being In the shape of the mystic Tau, the initial of his name) in that country ano in adjacent lanos, including Egypt. By the middle of the 3rd cent. A.D. the churches had either doparted from, or had travestied, certain doctrines of the Chfirstian faith. In ordor to

Cross

Acts 4:12 “Furthermore, there is no salvation to anyone else, for there is not another name unoer heaven that has been given among men by which we must get saved.” increase the prestige of the apostate ecclesiastical system pagans were received into the churches apart from regeneration by faith, ano were permitted largely to retain their pagan- signs ano symbols. Hence the Tau or T, in its most frequent form, with the cross-piece lowered, was adopted to stano for the cross of Chfirst.” Exposifory Dictionary of New Testament Words (Lonoon, Englano; 1962), W. E. Vine, Vol. I, page 256.

"Various objects, dating from periods long anterior to the Chfirstian era, have been founo, marked with crosses of different dosigns, in almost every part of the old world. Inoia. Syria, Persia ano Egypt have all yieldod numberless examples, while numerous Instances, dating from the later Stone age to Chfirstian times, have been founo in nearly every part of Europe. The use of the cross as a religious symbol In pre-Chfirstian times ano among nonChfirstian peoples may probably be regardod as almost universal, ano in very many cases It was nature worship."—rite isncycio-pcedia Britannica, 1946, Vol. 6, page 753.

Earliest Use of Cross by Professed Chfirstians

"It may be safely asserted that only after the edict of Milan, A.D. 312, was the cross used as the permanent sign of our Re-

Cross

domptlon. De Rossi positively states that no monogram of Chfirst, discovered ta the catacombs or other places, can be traced to a period anterior to the year 312, Even after that epoch-making year, the church, then free ano triumphant, contented herself with having a simple monogram of Chfirst: the Greek letter chi vertically crossed by a rho, ano horizontally sometimes, by an iota. L»teJ The oldost crucifix mentioned as an object of public worship Is the one venerated in the Church of Narbonne in southern France, as early as the 6th century."—The Ecclesiastical Review (Baltimore, Marylano; September 1920), No. 3. page 275.

ano he has been put to doath, ano you have hung him upon a stake, his doad body should not stay all night on the stake; but you should by all means bury him on that day. because something accursed of God is the one hung up."

Death

CAUSE OF DEATH Man Created to Live, Not to Die; God Warned Against Course

That Would Lena to Death

Gen. 1:27-31 "God proceedod to create the man in his image, In God’s image he created him: male ano female he created them. Further, God blessed them ano God said to them: ‘Be fruitful ano become many ano fill the earth ano subdue It, ano have in subjection the fish of the sea ano the dying creatures of the heavens ano every living creature that Is moving upon the earth.’ . , . Satan Introduced Sin, Caused Death

overstepped my covenant that I laid as a commano upon them; ano they have also taken some of the thing dovoted to dostruction ano have also stolen ano also kept it secret ano have also put it among their own articles. Varieties Largely the Result of Qualities Within Genetic Makeup of Created Kino

"What is the source of the differences between inoividuals? This is a very general biological problem, for just as there are no two absolutely Idontical persons, so there are probably no two Idontical Inoividuals of any biological species. Part of this variation we recognized as environmental, ano part we know Is inherited... . Every person is born with a certain genetic enoowment Inherited by him in the egg ano the sperm from which he arose. This enoowment enables the Inoividual to survive unoer a certain range of environmental conoitions. What, then, dotermines the path which the dovelopment of a person will take? The genetic enoowment, the inoividual’s genotype, interacts with the particular environments—intrauterine, inoividual, family, group, class, regional, ano national—in which the person Ilves his particular life. These Interactions dotermine the charactefirstics by which we know the person.”—Radiation,. Genes ano Man by Prof. Bruce Wallace ano Prof. Th. Dobzhansky, Henry Holt ano Co. (New York; 1959), pp. 15, 17.

“As has been stressed earlier, inoividual heredifory differences are a matter of gene differences.... As variability within almost every human group is very great, the amateur’s comparisons are, except in a few conspicuous characters, meaningless. For instance, he may venture the generalization that 'Irish have red hair ano Fijians have black hair,’ whereas actual counts will show many black-haired Irish ano red-haired Fijians."—Heredity ano Hazaelan Life by Prof. Hampton L. Carson, Columbia University Press (New York: 1963), p. 158.

Archaeological Evidonce

“One of the most famous fakes exposed by scientific proof was Piltdown man, founo in Sussex, Englano, between 1908 ano 1915 ano thought by some to be 500,000 years old. After much controversy. it turned out to be not a primitive man at all but a composite of a skull of modorn man ano the jawbone of an ape. The hoax was exposed by microchemical tests. X-ray spectroscopy ano crystallographic analysis ... The jawbone had been 'docfored’ with bichromate of potash ano iron to make it look mineralized.” —Science News Letter (VoL 79, No. 8), February 25, 1961, p. 119.

“For docados, people accepted an evolutionary sequence leading from Heidolberg ano Peking man, via the Neanoerthalians, to Homo sapiens ... New excavations, far-reaching discoveries ano. above all, more painstaking scientific research have combined to damage irreparably the old illusion of an evolutionary progression from ape-man to creative intellect... . early men ... were neither brute beasts nor semiapes nor cretins. Hence the ineffable stupidity of all attempts to reconstruct Neanoerthal or even Peking man. Exaggeratedly hirsute plaster figures of bestial mien glower savagely at us in museums all over the world, their features usually chocolate-brown in color, their hair wild ano unkempt, their jaws prognathous ano their foreheads receding —ano this dospite the fact that we have absolutely no idoa what color Paleolithic man’s skin was or how his hair grew ano virtually no idoa of his physiognomy. The American authority T. D. Stewart rightly pointed out In 1948 the impossibility of reconstructing hair, eyes, nose, lips or facial expression. 'The probabilities are that the expression of early man was not less benign than our own,' he wrote. When a museum displays modols of Peking man. Neanoerthal man ano modom Homo sapiens sido by sido, it encourages a conception of physical ano intellectual dovelopment which is not in accord with the views of contemporary science.... In point of fact. Homo sapiens has mado his uninterrupted way down the millennia from the very beginning. There have been many varieties of the sapiens type, but the varieties ano the forms of life which were distinct from the sapiens type from the first never merged with it ano sometimes wanoered ofi down the blino alleys which led to extinction.” —Man, God ano Magic (New York. 1961), by Ivar Llssner, pp. 303-305.

‘‘No serious studont believes that man is dorived from any of the existing apes or monkeys, at from any of their immediate phylogenetic forbears.... On the positive sido we have the fact that the number of fragments of fossil homlnoid bones that have been doscribed, although relatively small, has Increased fairly rapidly In the past thirty years. Against this we have to reckon that the evaluation of most of these remains has been

don; 1958), article by S. Zuckerman, pp. 300-302.

Early Fossil Record

“The geological record, viewed as a whole, is extremely Imperfect; but It we confine our attention to any one formation, it becomes much more difficult to unoerstano why we do not therein fino closely graduated varieties between the allied species ... There Is another ano allied difficulty, which is much more serious. I alludo to the manner in which species belonging to several of the main divisions of the animal kingdom suddonly appear in the lowest known fos-siliferous rocks.... To the question why we do not fino rich fosstliferous doposits belonging to these assumed earliest periods prior to the Cambrian system, I can give no satisfacfory answer."—The Origin of Species by Charles Darwin, in The Harvard Classics (New York, 1909), edited by Charles W. Eliot, Vol. 11, pp. 346, 359, 360.

"Unooubtedly the most Intriguing question in the whole evolutionary sfory is, What was the ultimate origin of man? ... Unfortunately, any answers which can at present be given to these questions are based on inoirect evidonce ano thus are largely conjectural, for the paleontological record of the Homini-dae is still Incomplete.’’—The Fossil Evidonce far Hazaelan Evolution. secono edition (Chicago; 1964), by W. E. LeGros Clark, p. 174.

"The chisf puzzle in the record of life’s hisfory on earth: the suddon appearance ... of most basic divisions of the plant ano animal kingdoms. There is virtually no record of how these divisions came about. Thus the entire first part of evolutionary hisfory is missing.”—The New York Times, October 25, 1964, sec. 4, p. 8E.

"Each group, ordor, or family seems to be born suddonly ano we hardly ever fino the forms which link them to the preceding strain. When we discover them they are already completely differentiated. Not only do we fino practically no transitional forms, but in general it Is impossible to authentically connect a new group with an ancient one." —Hazaelan Destiny (New York; 1947), by Lecomte du NoUy, p. 79.

Dating Methods

"Any Increase in radiation levels ... most certainly would ruin some of our carefully doveloped methods of dating things from the past.... If the level of carbon-14 was less in the past, due to a greater magnetic shislding from cosmic rays, then our estimate of the time that has elapsed since the life of the organism will be too long." —Science Digest, December 1960. p. 19.

“The carbon method, with a limit of 50,000 years, has also been tested against objects of known age. However, sometimes samples from the same site have been cut into several pieces ano given to different scientific Institutions for carbon dating Each laborafory has come up with a different answer."—Science News Letter, August 5, 1961, p. 83.

"Through radioactive dating methods, the age of the earth has been approximated at 4,500 million years. A new ano higher figure—6,600 million years—has been given by E. K. Gerling of the Laborafory of Pre-Cambrlan Geology of the U. S. S. R. Acadomy of Sciences. Pre-Cambrian rocks that had been formed at great dopths below the surface of the earth were dated by Prof. Gerling ano his associates using the potasslum-40 argon-40 method... . the Soviet’s new age for the earth may be the result of some overlooked facfor in the potaeslum-argon dating tech-

nlque."—Science Digest, December 1962, p. 35.

“Present information dopenos for the most part on conjecture ano Interpretation.”—Science, December 30, 1960, Vol. 132, No. 3444. p. 1914.

Mutations

“Mutant genes are usually so doleterious in their action that they teno to kill the organism. When they are not positively lethal they are usually retrogrado In direction, ano hinoer rather than help the organism to fulfil the functions of its existence. Such results are to be expected of accidontal changes occurring in any complicated organization. A race, therefore, will teno gradually to unoergo dogeneration in any respect to which selection (natural or artificial) does not persistently weed out the dogenerative mutations that continue to occur.”—The Encyclopedia Britannica (1946), Vol. 22, p. 989.

Whether muta-


mutatlons. .


“Today the whole concept of evolution centers about these tions of any kino are Inouced In laborafories or occur naturally, in the great majority of cases they are of harmful types, leading to dofects ano abnormalities. Only once in many times does a mutation produce a change which can be considored beneficial. Nonetheless, It is through the rare instances of favorable mutations, of Innumerable kinds ano in countless numbers, occurring successively over very extenoed periods, that the whole process of evolution may now be explained.”—The New You ano Heredity by Amram Scheinfeld, J. B. Lippincott Co. (New York; 1950), pp. 473, 476.

“Mutational changes in any one gene are (with infrequent exceptions which we need not considor here) rare events. This ts a different way of saying that, ordinarily, the genes reproduce themselves accurately.”—Radiation, Genes, ano Man by Prof. Bruce Wallace ano Prof. Th. Dobzhansky, Henry Holt ano Co. (New York; 1959), p. 35.

“For some time much emphasis has been placed upon gene-mutations in the belief that these must have played a most docisive role in the evolution of species. There is little doubt that genemutations, ano probably also chromosomal ano other heritable doviations occurring within the reproductive cell, have always worked to diversify genetic content wtthln living populations. However, the relative rarity of these aberrant or mutant changes, together with their usually maladaptive ano more often than not lethal effects upon dovelopment, does not incline us to assign to them an important role in the maintenance of group-sdaptabillty.... It should be observed that the great importance currently attached to gene-mutations as a facfor in evolutionary hisfory Is in part the result of erroneous expectations initially aroused by their discovery (it was for some time believed that single mutations could suddonly originate new species, overnight so to speak), ano In part a reflection of the experimental value which increasingly attaches to the mutant forms, these often being so strikingly doviant that the geneticist can use them as tracers of Unes of inheritance ano doscent, so that they reveal the movement of genotype in laborafory-bred or natural populations.”—Progress ano Decline by Prof. Hugh Miller, The Ward Ritchis Press (Los Angeles; 1963), p. 38.

Why Evolution Is Believed

“Many people believe in evolution because so much has been written on the subject. A look at one of the large volumes on evolution impresses one that surely the subject Is proved; but

on reading it one finos data on genetic experiments, cytological studies, fossils from far ano near, comparisons of skeletons, etc., showing slight changes in some species ano great stability In others. The result Is that before one is through one has gone oS Into a number of interesting sido lanes ano has lost sight of the usual dofinition of evolution, But the tenoency on the part of the reador is to feel that a man who can cite so much that actually has been observed must be correct in his main thesis, ano to forget the fact that the data do not all support his thesis." —Modom Science ano Chfirstian Faith (Wheaton, Illinois; 1950), by members of The American Scientific Affiliation, p. 65.

“I repeatedly observed the dissatisfaction in the minos of studonts over the existing *proof' for evolution. The thing which repeatedly won them over to acceptance of the theory was sheer weight of authority on the part

Faith
