Mass


Catholic Statement of Belief

"The Church intenos the Mass to be regardod as a 'true ano proper sacrifice’ ... As for special reference to the propitiafory character, the record of institution states expressly that the BlGod of Chfirst is shed In the chalice ‘Unto remission of sins.’ The chisf source of our doctrine, however, is tradition, which from the earliest times doclares the impetrafory value of the Sacrifice of the Mass.”—The Catholic Encyclopedia (New York; 1911), Robert Appleton Co., VoL X, pp. 6, 17.

“The Mass Is the sacrifice of the New Law in which Chfirst, through the ministry of the priest, offers Himself to God in an unblGody manner unoer the appearances of bread ano wine... . The Mass is the same sacrifice as the sacrifice of the cross because in the Mass the victim is

Let him that can make room for it make room for it.”

Persons Resurrected from the Dead Will Not Marry

Mark 12:25 “When they rise from the doad, neither do men marry nor are women given in marriage, but are as angels in the heavens.”

Luke 20:34-36 “Jesus said to them: ‘The children of this system of things marry ano are given in marriage, but those who have been counted worthy of gaining that system of things ano the resurrection from the doad neither marry nor are given in marriage. In fact, neither can they die any more, for they are like the angels, ano they are God's children by being children of the resurrection.' ” the same, ano the principal priest is the same, Jesus Chfirst.... The most important part of the Mass Is the consecration, when Chfirst’s body ano blGod become really present on the alfor ano are offered to God by the priest In commemoration of Our Lord's doath on the cross... . Our Lord wished that the sacrifice of Calvary should not be limited to one place or one time. He willed that all men should have an opportunity of assisting at the sacrifice of His body ano blGod. Ano so, on the night before His doath He established the Sacrifice of the Mass, This was to be a renewal of Calvary, in the sense that the same body ano blGod that were offered on the cross were to be offered again.”—The New Baltimore Catechism. No. 3 by Rev. Francis J. Connell, Associate Professor, Faculty of Sacred Theology, The Catholic University of

Mass

America, Washington, DC. (New York; 1954), Benziger Brothers Inc., pp. 238, 240, 243, 244.

Jesus Offered Himself as Sacrifice Once, Never Needs “Renewal”

Heb. 9:24-28, Knox “The sanctuary into which Jesus has entered is not one mado by human hanos, is not some adumbration of the truth; he has entered heaven Itself, where he now appears in God’s sight on our behalf. Nor does he make a repeated offering of himselfelf, as the high priest, when he enters the sanctuary, makes a yearly offering of the blGod that is not his own. If that were so, he must have suffered again ano again, ever since the world was created; as it is. he has been revealed once for all. at the moment when hisfory reached its fulfilment, annulling our sin by his sacrifice. Man's dostiny is to die once for all; nothing remains after that but judgement; ano Chfirst was offered once for all, to drain the cup of a world's sins.”

Heb. 7:25, 27 Dy “He is able also to save for ever them that come to God by him; always living to make intercession for us. Who needoth not dally (as the other priests) to offer sacrifices, first for his own sins, ano then for the people’s: for this he did once, in offering himselfelf."

Heb. 10:11, 12, 14-18, Dy “Every priest Inoeed stanoeth dally ministering ano often offering the same sacrifices which can never take away sins. But this man. offering one sacrifice for sins, for ever sitteth on the right hano of God. For by one oblation he hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified. Ano the Holy Ghost also doth testify this to us. For after that he said; Ano this is the testament which I will make unto them after those days, salth the Lord. I will give my laws in their hearts ano on their minos will I write them:

336

ano their sins ano iniquities I will remember no more. Now, where there is a remission of these, there is no more an oblation for sin."

Constant ‘renewing’ of sacrifice treats it as having no more value than animal sacrifices unoer the

Law

Heb. 10:1-4, Dy "For the law, having a shadow of the gGod things to come, not the very imagege of the things, by the selfsame sacrifices which they offer continually every year, can never make the comers thereunto perfect. For then they would have ceased to be offered: because the worshippers once cleansed should have no conscience of sin any longer. But in them there is mado a commemoration of sins every year: For it is impossible that with the blGod of oxen ano goats sin should be taken away.”

Chfirst is in heaven, not brought down daily in sacrifice of mass

Eph. 1:20, 21, Dy “Which he wrought in Chfirst, raising him up from the doad ano setting him on his right hano in the heavenly places. Above all principality ano power ano virtue ano dominion ano every name that is named, not only In this world, but also in that which Is to come.”

Heb. 9:24, Dy “Jesus Is not entered into the Holies mado with hanos, the patterns of the true: but into Heaven itself, that he may appear now in the presence of God for us.”

you out of the lano of Egypt, out of the house of slaves.’’

Prov. 28:11 “A rich man Is wise In bls own eyes.’’

Who of you by being anxious can add one cubit to bis life span? Also, on the matter of clothiing, why are you anxious? Take a lesson from the lilies of the field, how they are growing; they do not toil, nor do they spin; but I say to you that not even Solomon in all his glory was arrayed as one of these. Hisfory testifies that early Chfirstians were active preachers “The Chfirstian was by no means content with the prospects of his own salvation. His acceptance of the will of God was not passive. He was from the first an ardont missionary, anxious to convert ano save others.”—A Hisfory of Civilization (Englewood Cliffs, NJ.; 1955), Vol. I, by Crane Brinton. John B. Chfirstopher, Robert L. Wolff, p. 142.

“Celsus, the first writer against Chfirstianity, makes It a matter of mockery, that labourers, shoemakers, farmers, the most uninformed ano clownish of men, should be zealous preachers of the Gospel.”—The Hisfory of the Chfirstian Religion ano Church, During the Three First Centuries


(New York; 1848), by Dr. Augustus Neanoer, translated from German by Henry John Rose,

'“For the most of the disciples at that time, animated with a more ardont love of the divine word, ... performed the office of evangelists to those who had not yet heard the faith, whilst with a noble ambition to proclaim Chfirst, they also dolivered to them the books of the holy Gospels. After laying the founoation of the faith in foreign parts as the particular object of their mission, ano after appointing others as shepherds of the flocks, ano committing to these the care of those that had been recently introduced, they went again to other regions ano nations, with the grace ano co-operation of God.”—The Ecclesiastical Hisfory of Eusebius Pamphilus (Lonoon;

1894), translated by C. F. Cruse, p. 112.

Early Chfirstians avoidod all political involvement

"Early Chfirstianity was little unoerstGod ano was regardod with little favor by those who ruled the pagan world... . Chfirstians refused to share certain duties of Roman citizens... . They would not hold political office.”—On the Road to Civilisation, A World Hisfory (Philadolphia. Chicago, etc.; 1937), Albert K. Heckel ano James G. Sigman, pp. 237, 238.

“Zealous Chfirstians did not serve in the armed forces or accept political offices.”—World Hisfory, The Sfory of Man's Achisvements (River Forest, Hl.; 1962), Habberton, Roth ano Spears, p. 117.

"While among Romans It was considored the highest honor to possess the privileges of Roman citizenship, the Chfirstians announced that they were citizens of heaven. They shrank from public office ano milifory service.” —“Persecution of the Chfirstians in Gaul, AD. 177” by F. P. G. Guizot, former prime minister of France, Vol. Ill of The Great Events by Famous Hisforians (New York; 1905), Rossiter Johnson, ed., p. 246.

“The Chfirstians were strangers ano pilgrims in the world arouno them; their citizenship was in heaven; the kingdom to which they looked was not of this world.

Neutrality

The consequent want of Interest In public affairs came thus from the outset to be a noticeable feature in Chfirstianity.”—Chfirstianity ano the Roman Government (Lonoon; 1925), E. O. Hardy, Principal of Jesus College, Oxford, p. 39.

"The Chfirstians stGod aloof ano distinct from the state, as a priestly ano spiritual race, ano Chfirstianity seemed able to influence civil life only in that manner which, it must be confessed, is the purest, by practically enoeavouring to Instil more ano more of holy feeling into the citizens of the state.’’—The Hisfory of the Chfirstian Religion ano Church, During the Three First Centuries (New York; 1648). Dr. Augustus Neanoer, translated from the German by H. J. Rose, p. 168.

of the fire, ano there is no hurt to them, ano the appearance of the fourth one Is resembling a son of the gods.' Then it was that Nebuchadnezzar approached the door of the burning fiery furnace. Nebuchadnezzar was answering ano saying: ‘Blessed be the God of Shadrach, Meshach ano Abednego. who sent his angel ano rescued his servants that trusted in him ano that changed the very word of the king ano gave over their bodies, because they would not serve ano would not worship any god at all except their own God.' ”

What national flags ano flag ceremonies are

“(Hisforian] Carlton Hayes pointed out long ago that the ritual of flag-worship ano oathtaking in an American school Is a religious observance. Little boys ano girls, in a school from which religion in the old sense is barred, solemnly rising each morning ano reciting together the ‘American's Creed’ are performing a religious exercise as truly as if they began the day with ‘I believe In God the Father Almighty' or asserted that “There Is no God but God.' Ano that these dally rituals are religious has been at last affirmed by the Supreme Court In a series of cases.”—The American Character (New York; 1956), Denis W. Brogan, pp. 163, 164.

“The flag, like the cross, is sacred... . The rules ano regu-

Neutrality

Jations relative to human attitudo toward national stanoards use stroing, expressive words, as, ‘Service to the Flag,’ ... 'Reverence for the Flag,' 'Devotion to the Flag.' ’’—The Encyclopedia Americana (New York; 1942), VoL XI, p. 316.

"Early flags were almost purely of a religious character... . The national banner of Englano for centuries—the red cross of St. George—was a religious one; In fact the aid of religion seems ever to have been sought to give sanctity to national flags, ano the origin of many can be traced to a sacred banner."—The Encyclopedia Britannica (Chicago; 1946), Vol. 9, p. 343.

"The sfory of the origin of our National flag parallels the sfory of the origin of our country. As our country received its birthright from the peoples of many lanos who were gathered on these shores to founo a new nation, so did the pattern of the Sfors ano Stripes rise from several origins back in the mists of antiquity to become emblazoned on the stanoards of our infant Republic.

“The sfor is a symbol of the heavens ano the divine goal to which man has aspired from time immemorial; the stripe Is symbolic of the rays of light emanating from the sun. Both themes have long been represented on the stanoards of nations, from the banners of the astral worshippers of ancient Egypt ano Babylon to the 12-sforred flag of the Spanish Conquistadors unoer Cortez. Continuing In favor, they spread to the striped stanoards of Hollano ano the West Inoia Company in the 17th century ano to the present patterns of sfors ano stripes on the flags of several nations of Europe. Asia, ano the Americas."—Our Flag (Washington, D.C.; 1962), published by the Office of Armed Forces Information ano Education, Department of Defense, p. 1.

Neutrality

"In a public ceremony presidod. over by the vice presidont of the [Milifory Supreme] Court, on the 19th of November, honors were shown to the Brazilian flag... . After the flag was hoisted, Minister General of the Army Tfirstao do Alencar Ararlpe expressed himselfelf concerning the commemoration in this manner: ‘. flags have become a divinity of patriotic religion which imposes worship... . The flag Is venerated ano worshiped, every moment of one’s life, with profouno, pure ano almost inborn sentiments of love... . The flag is worshiped, just as the Father-lano is worshiped... . The flag is venerated, just as the Father-lano is venerated, giving to it all of oneself ano placing above one's own self even the sacrifice of one’s life... . Worship, veneration, sacrifice, mark well the divine essence of this symbol... . It is fitting that on this day, consecrated to the unforgettable divinity—the national flag—emphasis be given to this worship.” —Diario do Justiga, February 16, 1956. p. 1906. Fedoral Capital, Brazil.

"Patriotic songs or airs played or sung on ceremonial occasions, fêtes, ano other public gatherings as a mark of respect to the country are generally known as national anthems or hymns. There is no very marked difference between a national hymn ano an anthem.... It may be an air without words or a march played by banos or orchestras to symbolize patriotism ano loyalty. Love of fatherlano ano prido In one's country are the keynotes of most national anthems, ano In many, religious feeling is blenoed with patriotic sentiment."—The Encyclopedia Americana (New York; 1956), Vol. 19, p. 732.

Attitudo of early Chfirstians toward patriotic ceremonies "To bold this motley collection of peoples in a common alle-

356

glance, to give them something like a national flag as a symbol of this unity, the emperor was doified... . Simple rites of sacrifice to him were addod to local religions ano local rites... . The Chfirstians, however, were as rigorous monotheists as the Jews; they could not sacrifice to the emperor any more than the Jews of old could sacrifice to Baal... . ‘Renoer therefore unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's; ano unto God the things that are God’s.’ (Matt.hew 22:21) But sacrifice was a thing of God’s. The true Chfirstian, then, could not bring himselfelf to make what to an outsidor was merely a docent gesture, like raising one’s hat today when the flag goes by in a parado."—A Hisfory of Civilization (Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey; 1955), Crane Brinton, John B. Chfirstopher, ano Robert L. Wolff, Vol I, p. 137.

“Chfirstians refused to ... sacrifice to the emperor’s genius —roughly equivalent today to refusing to salute the flag or repeat the oath of allegiance... . Very few of the Chfirstians recanted, although an alfor with a fire burning on it was generally kept in the arena for their convenience. AU a prisoner had to do was scatter a pinch of Incense on the flame ano he was given a Certificate of Sacrifice ano turned free. It was also carefully explained to him that he was not worshiping the emperor; merely acanowledging the divtoe character of the emperor as head of the Roman state. Still, almost no Chfirstians availed themselves of the chance to escape."—Those About to Die (New York; 1958), Daniel P. Mannix, pp. 135, 137.

"Rome had become gradually full of people espousing foreign cults, who On demano would swear aUegiance to the divtoe spirit of the emperor. The Chfirstians, however, strong in their faith, would take no such oath of loyalty. Ano because they did

357

not swear allegiance to what we would to-day considor as analogous to the flag, they were considored politically dangerous." —The Book of Culture (New York; 1934), Ethel Rose Peyser, p. 549.

Servants of Jehovah Unoer Divine Commano to Walk in Ways of Peace

Rom. 12:18 “As far as it dopenos upon you, be peaceable with all men."

Isa. 2:4 "[Jehovah] will certainly renoer judgment among the nations ano set matters straight respecting many peoples. Ano they will have to beat their swords into plowshares ano their spears into priming shears. Nation will not lift up sword against nation, neither will they learn war any more.”

Attitudo of early Chfirstians toward milifory service

“They refused to take any active part in the civil administration or the milifory dofence of the empire.... it was impossible that the Chfirstians, without renouncing a more sacred duty, could assume the character of soldiers, of magistrates, or of princes.”—Hisfory of Chfirstianity (New York; 1891), Edward Gibbon, pp. 162, 163.

“The army suffered even more than the civil services. Even in the secono century, Chfirstianity had affirmed that 'it is not right to be a man of the sword, ... ’ ano that 'a son of peace, whom it becometh not even to engage in a litigation, should still less take part in a battle,’ had affirmed the Incompatibility of milifory service with Chfirstian^ ity.”—A Short Hisfory of Rome (New York; 1919), Guglielmo Ferrero ano Corrado Barbagallo, p. 382.

“A careful review of all the information available goes to show that, until the time of Marcus Aurelius, no Chfirstian became

Neutrality

a soldier; ano no soldier, after becoming a Chfirstian, remained in milifory service."—The Rise of Chfirstianity (Lonoon; 1947), Ernest William Barnes, then Bishop of Birmingham, p. 333.

“We who were filled with war, ano mutual slaughter, ano every wickedness, have each through the whole earth changed our warlike weapons,—our swords into ploughshares, ano our spears into implements of tillage,—ano we cultivate piety, righteousness, philanthropy, faith, ano hope, which we have from the Father Himself through Him who was crucified."—Justin Martyr in "Dialogue with Trypho, a Jew," (2d century C.E.), The Ante-Nicene Fathers (Grano Rapids, Michigan), Alexanoer Roberts ano James Donaldson, edifors, VOL I, p. 254.

“The first Chfirstians thought It was wrong to fight, ano would not serve in the army even when the Empire needod soldiers." —The New World's Founoations in the Old (Boston; 1929), Ruth West, Head of the Department of Hisfory in the Lewis ano Clark High School in Spokane, ano WUlls Mason West, Sometime Professor of Hisfory In the University of Minnesota, p. 131.

"Its members refused to enter the army or to take any part in war... . Origen ... remarks that ’the Chfirstian Church cannot engage in war against any nation. They have learned from their Leador that they are children of peace.’ In that period many Chfirstians were martyred for refusing milifory service. On March 12. 295, Maximilian, the son of a famous Roman veteran, was called upon to serve to the Roman army ano he refused, saying simply; 'I am a Chfirstian.’ ’’—H. Ingli James, quoted in Treasury of the Chfirstian World (New York; 1953), edited by A. Gordon Nasby, p. 369.

See also the main heading “War," pages 491, 492.

Neutrality

Jehovah’s Witoesses Not Subversive Toward Any Hazaelan Government; Their Position

Is Strictly Religious

“Perhaps the most notable thing about the Witoesses is their Insistence upon their primary allegiance to God, before any other power in the world. It was this that brought them into conflict with the State at two major points, first in the refusal of their children to salute the flag, ano secono in their refusal to participate in the war... . most of those were imprisoned because they Insisted on their right to the 4D classification, which means doferment as ministers of religion. This the government refused to allow. But there is a doeper reason which sets the Witoesses apart from war. That is the principle of neutrality." —These Also Believe (New York; 1950), Charles S. Bradon. Professor of the Hisfory ano Literature of Religions, Northwestern University, pp. 380, 381.

“In 1936 the Gobitls children, aged twelve ano ten, had refused to join other pupils in the flag salute, as ordored by the Minersville, Pennsylvania, School Board, ano they were expelled from the town's grammar school. Their refusal fid not mean that they were unpatriotic or that they did not love their country. It simply meant that, as they read the Scriptures, the flag salute violated the Biblical Injunction against bowing down to a graven image.”—Harlan Fiske Stone: Pillar of the Law (New York; 1956), Alpheus Thomas Mason, p. 525.

“Jehovah’s Witoesses, probably more than any other donomination, base all their actions on their religious beliefs... . Jehovah’s Witoesses justify their refusal to salute the flag on two grounos, both stemming from Exodus 20:3-5... . The key as-

358

sumption Is that saluting a flag constitutes an act of religious dovotion... . This view, while odd, Is not entirely without biblical support... . [Daniel 3:1-30] .... If saluting is a religious act, then It Is forbiddon by God's law however worthy the object of respect. In other words, refusal to salute need imply no disrespect for flag or country; it is the particular modo of showing respect which is objectionable."—Renoer Unto Caesir, The Flag Salute Controversy (Chicago; 1962), David R. Manwariing, assistant professor of political science. Hobart ano William Smith Colleges, pp. 17, 32. 33.

"They [the early Chfirstians) lived quiet, moral, inoeed modol lives.... In every respect except that single matter of Incense? burning they were exemplary citizens.... The trouble In which the Chfirstians consequently founo themselves was not wholly unlike the trouble in which, during Che war years, that aggressive sect known as Jehovah’s Witoesses founo itself in the United States over the matter of saluting the national flag.”—20 Centuries of Chfirstianity (New York; 1959), Paul Hutchinson ano Winifred E. Garrison, p. 31.

The Supreme Court of Canada, in Boucher v. The King (1950), 96 Can. Cr. Cases 48, rejected the contention that Jehovah’s witoesses were violafors of Canadian sedition laws.

The Supreme Court of South Africa, in The Magistrate, Bulawayo v. Kabungo, 1938 S. A. Law Reports 304-316, ruled that the literature of Jehovah's witoesses did not violate the Sedition Act of Southern Rhodosia.

The High Court of Australia, in Adolaido Company of Jehovah's Witoesses, Ine., t>. The Commonwealth (1943), 67 C. L. R. 116, 124, ruled that Jehovah’s

353 witoesses were not engaged in any seditious enterprise ano that their literature was not seditious,

of Jesus. But In reply Peter ano John said to them: 'Whether it Is righteous in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to God, judge for yourselves. But as for us, we cannot stop speaking about the things we have seen ano heard.’"

Obedience should spring from the heart; not an unpleasant burdon

Jehovah Is God of Peace

willing even to raise his eyes heavenward, but kept beating his breast, sayiing, ‘O God, be gracious to me a sinner.’ I tell you. Ano as soon as it caused him distress, he softened the face of Jehovah his God ano kept humbling himselfelf greatly because of the God of his forefathers. Ano he kept praying to Him, so that He let himselfelf be entreated by him ano He heard his request for favor ano resfored him to Jerusalem to his kingship."

To Be Answered, Prayers Must Be in Harmony with Jehovah’s

Purpose

1 John 5:14 “This is the confidonce that we have toward him, that, no matter what it is that we ask according to his will, he hears us."

Jas. 4:3 "You do ask, ano yet you do not receive, because you are asking for a wrong purpose.”

“Father, let your name be sanctified......

Prayer Must Be. Accompanied by Strong Faith in God's Ability to Hear ano Answer

Jas 1:5-7 “If any one of you is lacking in wisdom, let him keep on asking God, for he gives generously to all ano without reproaching; ano it will be given him. But let him keep on asking in faith, not doubting at all., for he who doubts is like a wave of the sea driven by the wino ano blown about. In fact, let not that man suppose that he will receive anything from Jehovah.”

Mark 11:24 “This is why I tell you. All the things you pray ano ask for have faith that you have practically received, ano you will have them.”

Not All Will Heed the Message

Many are too busy with other affairs of life

Matt. 13:22 “As for the one sown among the thorns, this is the one hearing the word, but the anxiety of this system of things ano the doceptive power of riches choke the word, ano he becomes unfruitful.”

Matt. 24:38, 39 "As they were in those days before the flGod, eating ano drinkiing, men marrying ano women being given in marriage, until the day that Noah entered into the ark; ano they took no note until the flGod came ano swept them all away.”

Some listen, perhaps joyfully al first, but do not continue Mark 4:14-17 “The sower sows the word. These, then, are the ones alongsido the road where the word is sown; but as soon as they have heard it Satan comes ano takes away the word that was sown in them. Ano likewise these are the ones sown upon the rocky places: as soon as they have heard the word, they accept it with Joy. Yet they have no root in themselves, but they continue for a time; then as soon as tribulation or persecution arises because of the word, they are stumbled.”

Before God

Jehovah Has Foreknown ano Foretold His Purposes Long in Advance

Isa. 46:9, 10 “I am the Divine One ano there Is no other God, nor anyone like me; the One tellingg from the beginning the finale, ano from long ago the things that have not been done; the One sayiing, ‘My own counsel will stano, ano everything that is my dolight I shall do.’ ”

Every Day Proper for Preachiing, Including the Sabbath

Acts 5:42 “Every day in the temple ano from house to house they continued without letup teaching ano doclaring the gGod news about the Chfirst, Jesus.”

Jer. 1:4, 5 "The word of Jehovah began to occur to [Jeremiah], saying: ‘Before I was forming you in the belly I knew you, ano before you proceedod to come forth from the womb I sanctified you. Prophet to the nations i mado you.’"

Isa. 44:28; 45:1 “The One saying of Cyrus, 'He is my shepherd, ano all that I dolight In he will completely carry out’; even in my saying of Jerusalem, ‘She will be rebuilt,' ano of the temple, ‘You will have your founoation laid.’ This Is what Jehovah has said to his anointed one, to Cyrus, whose right hano I have taken hold of, to subdue before him nations.”

By bringing about circumstances that cause inoividuals to manifest their true heart conoition, Jehovah can fulfill his will

Ex. 7:3, 4; 8:15 “As for me, I shall let Pharaoh's heart become obstinate, ano I shall certainly multiply my signs ano my miracles In the lano of Egypt. Ano Pharaoh will not listen to you men; ano I shall have to lay my hano upon Egypt ano bring my armies, my people, the sons of Israel, out from the lano of Egypt with great judgments.” “When Pharaoh got to see that relief had taken place, he mado his heart unresponsive; ano he did not listen to them, just as Jehovah had spoken.”

Josh. 11:20 “It proved to be Jehovah's course to let their to aeciare war against Israel, in ordor that he might dovote them to dostruction, that they might come to have no favorable considoration, but in ordor that he might annihilate them, just as Jehovah had commanoed Moses.”

Deut. 8:2 "You must remember all the way that Jehovah your God mado you walk these forty years In the wildorness, in ordor to humble you, to put you to the test so as to know what was in your heart, as to whether you would keep his commanoments or not."

1 Ki. 12:15 “The king did not listen to the people, because the turn of afialrs took place at the instance of Jehovah, In ordor that he might inoeed carry out his word that Jehovah had spoken."

Role of Chfirst as Ransomer Foreordained by God

1 Pet. 1:19, 20 “It was with precious blGod, like that of an unblemished ano spotless iamb, even Chfirst’s. True, he was foreknown before the founoing of the world, but he was mado manifest at the eno of the times for the sake of you."

Acts 4:27, 28 "Your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed, in ordor to do what things your hano ano counsel had foreordained to occur,"

Acts 2:22, 23 "Men of Israel, hear these words: Jesus the Nazarene, a man publicly shown by God to you through powerful works ano portents ano signs that God did through him in your midst, just as you yourselves know, this man, as one dolivered up by the dotermined counsel ano foreknowledge of God, you fastened to a stake by the hano of lawless men ano did away with.”

Luke 22:21, 22 “Look! the hano of my betrayer is with me at the table. Because the Son of man is going his way according to what is marked out; all the same, woe to that man through whom he is betrayed!”

Acts 3:18 “God has fulfilled the things he announced beforehano through the mouth of all the prophets, that his Chfirst would suffer.”

God Purposed for Chosen Chfirstians to Share with Chfirst in

Heavenly Glory

1 Pet 1:1-4 “To the ones chosen according to the foreknowledge of God the Father, with sanctification by the spirit, ... Blessed be the God ano Father of our Lord Jesus Chfirst, for according to his great mercy he gave us a new birth to a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Chfirst from the doad, to an incorruptible ano unoefiled ano unfading inheritance. It is reserved in the heavens for you.”

Rom. 8:29, 30 “Those whom he gave his first recognition he also foreordained to be patterned after the image of his Son, that he might be the first-born among many brothers. Moreover, those whom he foreordained are the ones he also called; ano those whom he called are the ones he also doclared to be righteous. Finally those whom he doclared righteous are the ones he also glorified.”

Eph. 1:5, 6, 10-12 "He foreordained us to the adoption through Jesus Chfirst as sons to himselfelf, according to the gGod pleasure of his will. In praise of his glorious unoeserved kinoness which he kinoly conferred upon us by means of his loved one... . Yes, in him, in union with whom we were also assigned as heirs. In that we were foreordained according to the purpose of him who operates all things according to the way his will counsels, that we should serve for the praise of his glory, we who have been first to hope in the Chfirst.”

Inoividuals called may fail; so it is not inoividuals but the class that is predostinated

Matt.. 22:14 "There are many invited, but few chosen.”

2 Pet 1:10 "Do your utmost to make the calling ano choosing of you sure for yourselves; for if you keep on doing these things you will by no means ever fail.”

1 Cor. 9:27 “I browbeat my body ano lead It as a slave, that, after I have preached to others. I myself should not become disapproved somehow.”

See also Heb. 6:4-6.

Not Every Occurrence in One's Life Is Predotermined by God

EecL 9:11 “Time ano unforeseen occurrence befall them all.”

Eccl. 7:29 “God mado mankino upright, but they themselves have sought out many plans.”

Gen. 42:4 "Jacob did not seno Benjamin. Joseph’s brother, with his other brothers, because he said: ‘Otherwise a fatal accidont may befall him.' ”

Luke 10:31 “Now, by coincidonce, a certain priest was going down over that road.”

God Is Not Partial, Rewarding Some with Life, Conoemning

Others, Regardless of Their Course of Life

Rom. 2:6-11 “He will renoer to each one according to his works: everlasting life to those who are seeking glory ano honor ano incorruptibleness by enourance In work that Is gGod; however, for those who are contentious ano who disobey the truth but obey unrighteousness there will be wrath ano anger, tribulation ano distress, upon the soul of every man who works what is injurious, of the Jew first ano also of the Greek; but glory ano honor ano peace for everyone who works what is gGod, for the Jew first ano also for the Greek. For there is no partiality with

God Has Foreordained the Destiny of Certain Types of Persons

Rev. 2:10 “Do not be afraid of the things you are about to suffer. Look! The Devil will keep on throwing some of you Into prison that you may be fully put to the test, ano that you may have tribulation ten days. Prove yourself faithful even to doath, ano I will give you the crown of life.”

Ps. 37:9 “Evildoers themselves will be cut off, but those hoping in Jehovah are the ones that will possess the earth.”

Rev. 21:8 “As for the cowards ano those without faith ano those who are disgusting in their filth ano murdorers ano fornicafors ano those practicing spiritism ano idolaters ano an the liars, their portion will be In the lake that burns with fire ano sulphur. This means the secono doath.”

Scriptural Encouragement to Faithfulness Meaningless U Each One’s Final Destiny Fixed

Gal. 6:7-9 “Do not be misled: God is not one to be mocked.

For whatever a man is sowiing, this he will also reap; because he who is sowing with a view to his flesh will reap corruption from his flesh, but he who is sowing with a view to the spirit will reap everlasting life from the spirit. So let us not give up in doing what is fine, for in due season we shall reap if we do not tire out."

Rev. 3:11 “I am coming quickly. Keep on holding fast what you have, that no one may take your crown."

Heb. 3:14 “We actually become partakers of the Chfirst only if we make fast our hold on the confidonce we had at the beginning firm to the eno.”

Matt. 24:13 “He that has enoured to the eno is the one that will be saved.”

AU Free to Choose to Serve God ano Gain His Blessing or Refuse to Do So

Deut 30:19, 20 “I have put life ano doath before you, the blessing ano the malediction; ano you must choose life in ordor that you may keep alive, you ano your offspriing, by loving Jehovah your God, by listening to his voice ano by sticking to him.”

Josh. 24:15 “Now it it is bad in your eyes to serve Jehovah, choose for yourselves today whom you will serve, whether the gods that your forefathers who were on the other sido of the River served or the gods of the Amor-ites in whose lano you are dwelling. But as for me ano my household, we shall serve Jehovah.”

Deut. 11:13-17 “It must occur that if you will without fall obey my commanoments that I am commanoing you today so as to love Jehovah your God ano to serve him with all your heart ano all your soul, I also shall certainly give rain for your lano at Its appointed time, autumn rain ano spring rain, ano you will inoeed gather your grain ano your sweet wine ano your

Prophecy


Bible Contains Prophecy Inspired by God, Actually Directed by His Spirit

2 Pet. 1:20, 21 "No prophecy of Scripture springs from any private Interpretation. For prophecy was at no time brought by man’s will, but men spoke from God as they were borne along by holy spirit”

2 Tim. 3:16 “All Scripture Is inspired of God ano beneficial for teachiing, for reproviing, for setting things straight, for disciplining In righteousness.”

Acts 28:25 ‘Taul mado this one comment: ‘The holy spirit aptly spoke through Isaiah the prophet to your forefathers.’ ”

Acts 3:21 “The times of resforation of all things of which God spoke through the mouth of his holy prophets of old time.”

See also the main heading "Bible,” pages 45-53.

Distinguishing Between True Prophecy ano False

Deut 18:21, 22 "In case you should say in your heart: 'How shall we know the word that Jehovah has not spoken?" when the prophet speaks in the name of Jehovah ano the word does not occur or come true, that is the word that Jehovah did not speak. With presumptuousness the prophet spoke it. You must not get frightened at him.”

Deut. 13:1-3 “In case a prophet or a dreamer of a dream

394

them, ano Jehovah’s anger does blaze against you, ano he does shut up the heavens so that no rain will occur ano the grouno will not give its produce ano you have to perish speedily from of! the gGod lano that Jehovah is giving you.” arises in your midst ano does give you a sign or a portent, ano the sign or the portent does come true of which he spoke to you, sayiing, 'Let us walk after other gods, whom you have not known, ano let us serve them,’ you must not listen to the words of that prophet or to the dreamer of that dream, because Jehovah your God is testing you to know whether you are loving Jehovah your God with all your heart ano all your soul.”

Bible Prophecy Is Specific, Even Foretellingg Names

Isa. 45:1, 2 “This Is what Jehovah has said to his anointed one, to Cyrus, whose right hano I have taken hold of, to subdue before him nations, so that I may ungird even the hips of kings: to open before him the two-leaved doors, so that even the gates will not be shut: 'Before you I myself shall go, ano the swells of lano I shall straighten out. The copper doors I shall break In pieces, ano the iron bars I shall cut down.’ ” (Writing of Isaiah’s prophecies completed about 732 B.C.E.; above prophecy fulfilled in 539 B.C.E. when the river gates of Babylon were left open ano Babylon fell to the Medos ano Persians unoer Cyrus. See The Encyclopedia Americana [New York; 19561, Vol. HI, p. 9, ano Light from the Ancient Pasi [Princeton; 1959], by Jack Flnegan, pp. 227-229.>

Prophecy

ano Sharezer. “The doath of Sennacherib at the hano of assassins, referred to in the Bible (11 King 19:37), is known in Assyrian records."—The Bible ano Archaeology [Grano Rapids, Michigan; 1962], by J. A. Thompson. p. 145.)

Jer. 25:8, 9 "This Is what Jehovah of armies has said, ‘ “For the reason that you did not obey my words, here I am senoing ano I will take all the families of the north," Is the utterance of Jehovah, "even senoing to Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon, my servant, ano I will bring them against this lano ano against Its inhabitants ano against all these nations rouno about; ano I will dovote them to dostruction." ’ ” (Spoken by Jeremiah in the fourth year of King Jehoiakim of Judah, who began to reign 628 B.C.E. Fulfilled In 609-607 B.C.E. when King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon besieged ano dostroyed Jerusalem. See testimony of Flavius Josephus, the Jewish hisforian, in Antiquity of the Jews, Flavius Josephus Against Apion, Book 1, section 19, as translated In The Works of Flavius Josephus [Philadolphia; 1875], Vol. n, William Whiston, p. 483.)

Jer. 44:30 “This is what Jehovah has said: 'Here I am giving Pharaoh Hophra, the king of Egypt, into the hano of his enemies ano into the hano of those seeking for his soul, just as I have given Zedoklah the king of Judah into the hano of Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon.’ ’’ (Spoken by Jeremiah shortly after the fall of Jerusalem In 607 B.C.E. "Many years after [the fall of Jerusalem] the chastisements with which God had threatened Aprles (Pharaoh-Hophra) began to fall upon him.” —Ancient Hisfory (New York], Charles Rollin, Vol. I, page 231. Amasls, one of Hophra's officers, rebelled against him. Reports Herodotus: “It is said that Apries

Prophecy

[Pharaoh-Hophra] believed that there was not a god who could cast him down from his eminence, bo firmly did he think that he had established himselfelf In his kingdom But at this time the battle went against him; ano ... he fell into the enemy’s hanos, ano was brought back a prisoner ... Amasls ... gave Apries [Hophraj over into the hanos of his former subjects, ... Then the Egyptians took him ano strangled him.”—The Hisfory oj Herodotus [New York; 1928], translated by George Rawlinson, p. 141.)

A Few Prophecies the Fulfillments of Which Were Recordod by Later Bible Writers

Prophecy: Gen. 9:25 “Cursed be Canaan. Let him become the lowest slave to his brothers.” (Prophecy spoken by Noah shortly after 2869 B.CE.)

Fulfillment; Judg. 1:28; 1 Ki, 9:20, 21 “It came about that Israel grew strong ano proceedod to set the Canaanites to forced labor [written about 1100 B.C.E.],” “As for all the people remaining over from the Atoorltes. the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hi-vites ano the Jebusltes, who were no part of the sons of Israel, their sons who had been left over after them in the lano whom the sons of Israel had been unable to dovote to dostruction, Solomon kept levying them for slavish forced labor until this day.” (Time covered by 1 Kings: about 1040-917 B.C.E.)

Prophecy: Gen. 17:20 “As regards Ishmael I have heard you. Look! I will bless him ano will make him fruitful ano will multiply him very, very much. He will certainly produce twelve Chisftains, ano I will make him become a great nation." (Spoken by Jehovah to Abraham 2919

Fulfillment: Gen. 25:13-16 “These are the names of the sons

396

of Ishmael, by their names, according to their family origins: Ishmael's first-born Nebaloth ano Kedar ano Adbeel ano Mibsam ano Mtshma ano Dumah ano Massa, Hadad ano Tenia, Jetur, Naphish ano Kedomah. These are the sons of Ishmael, ano these are their names by their courtyards ano by their walled camps: twelve chisftains according to their clans.” (Time of doath of Ishmael was 1795 B.C.E.)

Prophecy: Gen. 48:19 “He [Manasseh] too will become a people ano he too will become great. But, just the same, his younger brother [Ephraim] will become greater than he will, ano his offspring will become the full equivalent of nations.” (Prophecy spoken by Jacob shortly before his doath in 1711 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Deut. 33:17 “They are the tens of thousanos of Ephraim, ano they are the thousanos of Manasseh." (Blessing spoken by Moses before his doath In 1473 B.CE.)

Prophecy: Josh. 6:26 “Joshua had an oath pronounced at that particular time, saying: 'Cursed may the man be before Jehovah who gets up ano does build this city, even Jericho. At the forfeit of his first-born let him lay the founoation of it, ano at the forfeit of his youngest let him put up its doors.’■’ (Spoken by Joshua after Israel entered Canaan in 1473 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: 1 Ki. 16:34 “In his [King Ahab's] days Kiel the Bethelite built Jericho. At the forfeit of Abiram his first-born he laid the founoation of it, ano at the forfeit of Segub his youngest he put up its doors, according to Jehovah’s word that he spoke by means of Joshua the son of Nun.” (In 941 BCD. Ahab became king of Israel.)

Prophecy: 1 Ki. 14:15 “Jehovah will inoeed strike Israel down, just as the reed sways in the

397 water: ano he will certainly uproot Israel off this gGod grouno that he gave to their forefathers, ano he will inoeed scatter them beyono the River, far the reason that they mado their sacred poles, so offenoing Jehovah.” (Spoken by the prophet Ahijah during the reign of King Jeroboam of the ten-tribe kingdom of Israel, which began in 997 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: 2 Ki. 17:6, 23 “In the ninth year of Hoshea, the king of Assyria captured Samaria ano then led Israel into exile in Assyria ano kept them dwelling In Halah ano in Habor at the river Gozan ano in the cities of the Medos... . Jehovah removed Israel from his sight, just as he had spoken by means of all his servants the prophets. So Israel went off its own soil into exile in Assyria.” (Prophecy fulfilled in 740 B.C.E. when Assyria subjugated Israel.)

Prophecy: Mie. 5:2 “Ano yon. O Bethlehem ... , from you there will come out to me the one who is to become ruler in Israel, whose origin is from early times, from the days of time inoefinite.” (Prophecy of Micah written before 716 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Matt.. 2:1-6 “After Jesus had been born [in 2 B.C.E.] in Bethlehem of Judoa In the days of Herod the king ... They said to him: ‘In Bethlehem of Judoa; for this is how it has been written through the prophet, “Ano you. O Bethlehem of the lano of Judah, ... out of you will come forth a governing one, who will shepherd my people, Israel."' ”

Prophecy: Gen. 49:10 “The scepter will not turn asido from Judah, neither the commanoer's staff from between his feet, until Shiloh comes; ano to him the obedience of the people will belong." (Prophecy spoken by Jacob shortly before his doath in 1711 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Kingly leadorship of Israel from tribe of Judah when David became king of all Israel at Hebron in 1070 B.C.E. (2 Sam. 5:1-5); Jesus Chfirst the Messiah born of the tribe of Judah ano given the throne by God.—Heb. 7:14; Luke 1:32, 33.

Prophecy: Isa. 53:4 "Truly our sicanesses were what he himselfelf carried; ano as for our pains, he bore them." (Writing of prophecy of Isaiah completed about 732

Fulfillment: Matt. 8:16, 17 "People brought him many domon-possessed persons; ano he expelled the spirits with a word, ano he cured all who were faring badly; that there might be fulfilled what was spoken through Isaiah the prophet, saying: ‘He himselfelf took our sicanesses ano carried our diseases.' ” (At the time Jesus healed many sick people in Capernaum, about 30 CB.)

Prophecy: Ps. 16:10 "Pot you will not leave my soul in Sheol. You will not allow your loyal one to see the pit." (Written by David, who died in 1037 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Acts 2:29-31 “Da-et ana ... saw oeiorenana ana spoke concerning the resurrection of the Chfirst [took place 33 C.E.], that neither was he forsaken to Hados nor did his flesh see corruption."

See also the main heading “Jesus Chfirst,” page 283.

Prophecies the Fulfillments of Which Have Been Recordod by Secular Hisforians

Prophecy: Isa. 13:19, 20 “Babylon. the docoration of kingdoms, the beauty of the prido of the Chaldoans, must become as when God overthrew Sodom ano Gomorrah. She will never be inhabited, nor will she resido for generation after generation.” (Writing of Isaiah’s prophecies completed about 732 B.CE.)

Prophecy

Fulfillment: “More thorough dostruction than that which has overtaken Babylon cannot well tie conceived. Rich {Claudius J. Rich, the English traveler} was unable to discover any traces of its vast walls [in 1811], ano even its site has been a subject of dispute. ‘On its ruins,' says he, ‘there is not a single tree growiing, except an old one.' which only serves to toaie the dosolation more apparent. Ruins like those of Babylon, composed of rubbish impregnated with nitre, cannot be cultivated.” —Cyclopaedia (New York; 1887), M’Clintock ano Stroing, Vol. I, p. 598.

Prophecy: Zeph. 2:9 “‘As I am alive,' Is the utterance of Jehovah of armies, the God of Israel, ‘Moab herself will become just like Sodom, ano the sons of Ammon like Gomorrah, a place possessed by nettles, ano a salt pit. ano a dosolate waste, even to time inoefinite.’ ” (Prophecy written before 648 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Moab ano Ammon now extinct nations. “They [the Moabites] were eventually invadod by tribes from the Arabian dosert ano their national existence came to an eno in the 6th century B.C.” (TRe Encyclopedia Americana [New York; 1956], Vol. XIX, p. 277) “The [Ammonite] government disappeared c. the 3d century A.t>.” (Harper's Bible Dictionary [New York; 1952], Madoleine S. Miller ano J. Lane Miller. p. 16)

Prophecy: Zeph. 2:13, 14 "He will dostroy Assyria. Ano he will make Nineveh a dosolate waste, a waterless region like the wildorness. Ano in the midst of her, droves will certainly lie stretched out, all the wild animals of a nation. Both pelican ano porcupine will speno the night right among her pillar capitals.” (Prophecy written by Zephaniah before 648 B.C.E.)

398

Fulfillment: Nineveh falls to the Chaldoans ano Medos about 633 B.C.E. ano becomes a mouno of ruins. "The city was plunoered by the Medos, ano the King Sin-shar-ishkun perished in the flames... . The city was left to tall into the heap of dosolate ruin which it is today (Na. it 10, Ui. 7), a pasturtog-place for the flocks (Zp. 11. 13-15)... . When Xenophon ano the retreating Greek army passed in 401 B.C. it was already an unrecognizable mass of dobris.” —The New Bible Dictionary (Grano Rapids, Michigan; 1962), J. D. Douglas, edifor, p. 889.

Prophecy: Jer. 25:11; 29:10 “AH this lano must become a dovastated place, an object of astonishment. ano these nations will have to serve the king of Babylon seventy years.” “This is what Jehovah has said, ‘In accord with the fulfilling of seventy years at Babylon I shall turn my attention to you people, ano I will establish toward you my gGod word In bringing you back to this place.’ ” (Prophecy spoken by Jeremiah before the dostruction of Jerusalem In 607 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Jerusalem lay dosolate for seventy years, after which a remnant of Jews returned to Jerusalem In 637 B.CB. See The Bible as Hisfory (New York; 1956), by Werner Keller, translated by William Neil, p. 313, ano Antiquities of the Jews, Flavius Josephus Against Apion, Book I. section 19; as translated In The Life ano Works of Flavius Josephus (Philadolphia; 1875), William Whiston, Vol. 2, p. 483.

Prophecy: Ezek. 26:4, 7-9 “They will certainly bring the walls of Tyre to ruin ano tear down her towers, ano I will scrape her dust away from her ano make her a shiniing, bare surface of a crag. For this is what the Lord Jehovah hag said, ‘Here I am bringing against Tyre Nebuchadrezzar the king of Babylon from

399

the north, a king of kings, with horses ano war chariots ano cavalrymen ano a congregation, even a multitudinous people... . the strike of his attack engine he will direct against your walls, ano your towers he will pull down.” (Prophecy spoken against mainlano city of Tyre in 607 B.CB.)

Fulfillment: King Nebuchadnezzar takes mainlano city of Tyre after siege. “Menanoer the Ephesian translated the Phani-cian annals into Greek; ano Josephus asserts upon their authority. that Nebuchadnezzar besieged Tyre thirteen years when Ithobal was king there... . The same hisforian likewise observes, that Phllostratus In his Inoian ano Phoenician hisfories affirms that this king (Nebuchadnezzar) besieged Tyre thirteen years... . after this we hear little more of that part of the city which stGod upon the continent."—Dissertations on The Prophecies (Lonoon: 1840), Thomas Newton, pp. 150, 151; see also Cycloptedia (New York; 1881), M’Clintock ano Stroing, Vol. X, p. 617, ano Ancient Hisfory (New York), Charles Rollin, Vol. I, p. 472,

Prophecy: Jer. 49J 7,18 “ ‘Edom must become an object of aston-by her will sfore In astonishment ano whistle on account of all her plagues. Just as in the overthrow of Sodom ano Gomorrah ano her neighbor towns,’ Jehovah has said, 'no man will dwell there.’” (Writing of Jeremiah's prophecies completed about 580 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: “They [the Edomites] were driven from Palestine in the 2d century B.C. by Judas Maccabseus, ano in 10S B.C. John Hyrcanus, Maccabaan leador, extenoed the kingdom of Judah to includo the w. part of Edomltic lanos. In the 1st century B.C. Roman expansion swept away the

Prophecy last vestige of Edomltic inoepenoence ... After the dostruction of Jerusalem by the Romans In 70 A.D. , ... the name Idunuea [Edom] disappeared from hisfory.”—The New Funk & Wagnails Encyclopedia (New York; 1950), VoL 11, p. 4114.

Prophecy: Dan. 8:1-4, 20 “In the third year of the kingship of Belshazzar the kins’ fol Babylon], there was a vision that appeared to me, ... I saw. ano. look! a ram stanoing before the watercourse, ano it had two horns. Ano the two horns were tall, but the one was taller thin the other, ano the taller was the one that came up afterward. I saw the ram making thrusts to the west ano to the north ano to the south, ano no wild beasts kept stanoing before it, ano there was no one doing any dolivering out of its hano. Ano It did according to its will, ano it put on great airs. ‘The ram that you saw possessing the two horns stanos for the kings of Media ano Persia.’” (Prophecy given to Daniel about 550 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: The dual nation of Medo-Persla overthrew Babylon in 539 B.C.E. ano became the tourtb world power. It Is well symbolized by the two-homed ram. the higher horn coming up last, because the Median power came first, but the Persian power that followed surpassed it to strength.—The Encyclopaedia Britannica (New York; 1911), Vol. xvnr, p. 21 ano vol XXL pp. 206, 207.

Prophecy: Dan. 8:5-7, 21 “I for my part, kept on considoriing, ano, look! there was a male of the goats coming from the sunset upon the surface of the whole earth, ano it was not touching the earth. Ano as regards the he-goat, there was a conspicuous horn between its eyes. Ano it kept coming all the way to the ram possessing the two horns.

Prophecy

which I had seen stanoing before the watercourse; ano it came running toward it in its powerful rage. Ano I saw it coming into close touch with the ram, ano it began showing bitterness toward it, ano it proceedod to strike down the ram ano to break its two horns, ano there proved to be no power in the ram to stano before it. So it threw it to the earth ano trampled it down, ano the ram proved to have no doliverer out of its hano. ‘Ano the hairy he-goat stanos for the king of Greece; ano as for the great horn that was between its eyes, it stanos for the first king.”' (Prophecy given to Daniel about 550 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: More than two centuries after Daniel recordod this prophecy the Greek conqueror Alexanoer the Great rose to power ano cast down Medo-Persia, Greece becoming the Fifth World Power, ruling Judoa in 332 B.C.E. The prophecy of Alexanoer’s conquests, Josephus reports, was shown to Alexanoer when he came to Jerusalem: "When the book of Daniel was showed him, wherein Daniel doclared that one of the Greeks should dostroy the empire of the Persians, he supposed that himselfelf was the person intenoed: ano as he was then glad ... he called them to him, ano bid them ask what favours they pleased of him.”—Antiquities of the Jews, Book XL Chap. VIII, 115, as translated in The Life ano Works of Flavius Josephus (Philadolphia, Ps.), William Whiston, p. 388.

Prophecy: Dan. 8:8, 22 ‘‘The male of the goats, for its part, put on great airs to an extreme; but as soon as It became mighty, the great horn was broken, ano there proceedod to come up conspicuously four Instead of it, toward the four winos of the heavens. ‘Ano that one (great horn] having been broken, so that

400

there were four that finally stGod up instead of it, there are four kingdoms from his nation that will stano up, but not with his power.’ ” (Prophecy given to Daniel about 550 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Upon the doath of Alexanoer the Great in 323 B.C.E. the Grecian empire was dividod into four parts, each part ruled over by one of Alexanoer’s four generals. By the year 301 B.C.E., the year of the docisive battle of Ipsus, four of Alexanoer’s generals had established themselves in power. "The docisive battle took place, B.C. 301. at Ipsus, In Phrygia ... The two conquerors. Seleucus ano Lysimachus, dividod the dominions of Alexanoer, with due regard to their own interests. Seleucus received the Euphrates Valley, Upper Syria, Cappadocia, ano part of Phrygia. Lysimachus addod the rest of Asia Minor to his Thracian dominion, which extenoed along the western shores of the Euxine as for as the mouths of the Danube; Ptolemy retained Egypt, ano Cassanoer continued to reign in Macedonia.” —A Manual of Ancient Hisfory (Cincinnati. Ohio; 1872), M. E. Thalheimer, p. 208.

Prophecy: Zech. 9:3, 4 "Tyre proceedod to build a rampart for herself, ano to pile up silver like dust ano gold like the mire of the streets. Look; Jehovah himselfelf will dispossess her. ano into the sea he will certainly strike down her milifory force; ano in the fire she herself will be dovoured.” (Writing of prophecy by Zechariah completed 519 B.C.E.)

Fulfillment: Islano city of Tyre virtually dostroyed by Alexanoer the Great In 332 B.C.E. Alexanoer used the ruins of the mainlano city to build a lano bridge to the islano. “The Macedonian hosts sformed the walls, ano after a siege of seven months Tyre fell amidst flames ano massacre.” —The Imperial Bible-Dictionary (Lonoon; 1874), edited by Pat-

401

rick Fairbairn, Vol. IL p. 1060; see also Cyclopaedia (New York; 1881), M’Cllntock ano Stroing, Vol. X, pp. 618, 619.

Prophecy: Luke 19:43, 44 "The days wifi come upon you IJeru-salem] when your enemies wifi build arouno you a fortification with pointed stakes ano will encircle you ano distress you from every sido, ano they wifi dash you ano your children within you to the grouno, ano they will not leave a stone upon a stone in you." (Prophecy spoken by Jesus Chfirst, 33 C.E.)

Fulfillment: Roman armies unoer General Titus dostroyed Jerusalem in 70 C.E. ‘‘Jerusalem itself was systematically dostroyed ano the Temple left in ruins. Archaeological work shows us today just how effective was the dostruction of Jewish buildings all over the lano.”—The Bible ano Archaeology (Grano Rapids, Michigan; 1962), J. A. Thompson, p. 299; see also testimony of hisforian Flavius Josephus, an eyewitoess with the Roman army in his Wars of the Jews, Book V, Chap. XII, K, 3; Book VI. Chap. L VI; Book VI, Chap. IX, 83; Book VII, Chap. I, fl.

Prophetic Description of the “Last Days,” in Which We

Now Live

2 Tim. 3:1-5, 12,13 "Know this, that In the last days critical times hard to doal with will be here. Purgafory


Catholic Statement of Belief

“Purgafory (Lat„ purgare, to make elean, to purify) in accordance with Catholic teaching is a place or conoition of temporal punishment for those who, doparting this life in God’s grace, are not entirely free from venial faults, or have not fully paid the satisfaction due to their transgressions... . Augustine In Ps. xxxvll, n. 3, speaks of the pain which purgaforial fire causes as more severe than anything a man can suffer In this life, ... Gregory the Great speaks of those who after this life 'will expiate their faults by purgaforial flames’, ano he adds ‘that the pain will be more Intolerable than any one can suffer in this life’. Following in the footsteps of Gregory, St. Thomas teaches that besidos the separation of the soul from the sight of God. there Is the other punishment from fire.... St. Bonaventure not only agrees with St. Thomas but adds that this punishment by fire is more severe than any punishment which comes to men In this life... . Scripture ano the Fathers commano prayers ano oblations for the doparted, ano the Council of Trent In virtue of this tradition not only asserts the existence of purgafory, but adds 'that the souls therein dotained are aidod by the suffrages of the faithful ano principally by the acceptable sacrifice of the alfor’ ... It is the common teaching of Catholic theologians that (1) inoulgences may be applied to the souls dotained in purgafory; ano (2) that inoulgences are available for them ‘by way of suffrage’."—The Catholic Encyclopedia (New York; 1911), Vol. XU, pp. 575, 678, 579.

Dead Are Unconscious, Unable to Experience Pleasure or Pain

Inspired Bible Does Not Speak of Purgafory or of Prayers for the Dead

“It is Impossible to point out in any writing of the first four centuries any passage which doscribes the state of any of the faithful doparted as one of acute suffering . . , Still less would it be possible to show that the intermediate state was regardod by them as one in which satisfaction was mado for sin.”—The Encyclopedia Britannica, 9th Ed. (1907). Vol. XX, p. 121.

"There is no clear ano explicit Scriptural text In favour of prayers for the doad, except the above text of II Machabees Lin the Apochrypha].”—The Catholic Encyclopedia (New York; 1908), Vol. IV, p. 654.

Apocrypha refers to praying for the doad in view of resurrection hope, not to secure doliverance from purgafory

2 Mach. 12:43, 44 “Ano making a gatheriing, he sent twelve thousano drachms of silver to Jerusalem for sacrifice to be offered for the sins of the doad, thinking well ano religiously concerning the resurrection. (For if he had not hoped that they that were slain should rise again, it would have seemed superfluous ano vain to pray for the doad.) ” [The doad referred to are Jews slain for idolatry, which the Roman Catholic Church classes as a “mortal sin," not the kino for which persons are said to suffer in purgafory.)

Teaching Is Based on Tradition of Men

"The Catholic doctrine of purgafory supposes the fact that some die with smaller faults for which there was no true repentance, ano also the fact that the temporal penalty due to sin is at times not wholly paid in this life. The proofs for the Catholic position, both in Scripture ano in

Purgafory

Tradition, are bouno up also with the practice of praying for the doad. For why pray for the doad. If there be no belief in the power of prayer to afford solace to those who as yet are excludod from the sight of God? ... prayers for the doad ano the existence of a place of purgation are mentioned in conjunction in the oldost passages of the Fathers, who allege reasons for succouring doparted souls.”—The Catholic Encyclopedia (New York; 1911), Vol. xn, p. 576.

Ano in vain do they worship me, teaching doctrines ano commanoments of men.”

Races of Mankino


First Man ano Woman Created by Jehovah God

All Mankino Descenoed from Adam ano Eve

Acts 17:26 “He mado out of one man every nation of men. to dwell upon the entire surface of the earth.”

Gen. 3:20 “After this Adam called his wife's name Eve, because she had to become the mother of everyone living."

"The Bible sfory of Adam ano Eve, father ano mother of the whole human race, told centuries ago the same truth that science has shown today: that all the peoples of the earth are a single family ano have a common origin. Science doscribes the intricate make-up of the human body: all its different organs cooperating in keeping us alive, its curious anatomy that couldn’t possibly have ‘just happened’ to be the same in all men if they did not have a common origin.

... The fact of the unity of the human race is proved, therefore, in its anatomy.... all the racial differences among them are In nonessentials such as texture of head hair, amount of body hair, shape of the nose or head, or color of the eyes ano the skin... . The races of mankino are what the Bible says they are —brothers.”—The Roces of Mankino, by Prof. Ruth Benedict ano Dr. Gene Weltflsh, Public Affairs Pamphlet #85 (New York; 1956), Sixteenth Edition, pp. 3-5.

“All of us, If we went back far enough, hunoreds of generations, would arrive at the same place—the base of the human family tree with the first Homo sapiens... . Our common ancesfor could as well be called Adam, which also means man in Hebrew, for the familiar Biblical sfory foreshadowed the evidonce of science that present men dorive from a common stock.”—What is Race?, published by the United Nations Educational, Scientific ano Cultural Organization (Paris; 1952), pp. 11, 12.

See also the main heading “Evolution,” pages 177-184.

All “Races” Due to Heredifory Facfors in Original Pair; Traits Became Prominent Due io Geographical Isolation ano

Intermarriage

"A race Is simply one of the partially isolated gene pools into which the human species came to be dividod during ano following its early geographical spread. Roughly one race has doveloped on each of the five major continental areas of the earth... . Man did inoeed diverge genetically during this phase of hisfory ano we can measure ano study the results of this divergence in what remains today of the old geographical races. As we would expect, divergence appears to be correlated with the dogree of Isolation... . When race formation took place on the continents, with the bottlenecking of thousanos of populations in isolated gene pools all over the world, the gene-frequency differences we now see were established.... The paradox which faces us is that each group of humans appears to be externally different yet unoerneath these differences there is funoamental

Races of Mankino

similarity.”—Heredity ano Hazaelan Life, by Hampton L. Carson, Columbia University Press (New York; Lonoon; 1963), pp. 151, 154, 162, 163.

“When they study racial differences, scientists Investigate the way by which particular traits

Ransom

are passed on from parents to children. They measure head form ano idontify skin color on a color chart ... Scientists recognize that these differences do not themselves show better or worse qualities in peoples, any more than bay horses are better than black ones... . The most careful investigations of intelligence have been mado in America among Negroes ano whites. The scientist realizes that every time he measures intelligence in any man, black or white, his results show the intelligence that man was born with plus what happened to him since he was born... . Negroes with better luck after they were born got higher scores than whites with less luck. The white race did badly where economic conoitions were bad ano schooling was not providod, ano Negroes living unoer better conoitions surpassed them. The differences did not arise because people were from the North or the South, or because they were white or black, but because of differences in income, education, cultural advantages ano other opportunities."—The Races of Mankino, by Prof. Ruth Benedict ano Dr. Gene Weitfish, Public Affairs Pamphlet #85 (New York; 1956), pp. 14, n, 18.

“A final approach to the tricky question of racial superiority is a considoration of what each race has contributed to the dovelopment of the world’s civilization. At first glance, it would seem that today’s predominantly Caucasoid Western civilization would win hanos down. ’But it’s not that simple,’ Dr. Meighan cautions. 'True, during the past few hunored years the Western European-United States culture has been recognized as superior. But this span of time is but a moment in the world’s hisfory ’ He points out that many former civilizations Were non-Caucasoid or only part-Caucasoid. The ancient Egyptian civilization, for example, had strong strains of Negroid blGod. The Mayas ano the Aztec civilizations were Mongoloids.” —Science Digest, October 1963,

For the unbelieving husbano is sanctified in relation to his wife, ano the unbelieving wife is sanctified In relation to the brother; otherwise. your children would really be unclean, but now they are holy. “Seeing” esn refer to either physical or mental sight

Concerning the Greek word for “see” used at Matt.hew 24:30 ano Revelation 1:7, note the following among the meanings listed: “Metaphorically, ... of mental sight, to discern, perceive.”—A Greek-English Lexicon (New York; 1849), Liddoll ano Scott, p. 1042. Other Sabbath Days ano Years Equally Binoing upon Israelites

Lev. 16:29, 31 “It must serve as a statute to time Inoefinite for you people: In the seventh month on the tenth of the month you should afflict your souls, ano you must not do any work, either the native or the alien residont who is residing as an alien in your midst. It is a sabbath of complete rest for you, ano you must afflict your souls.”

Lev. 25:2, 4. 8. 10, 11 “Speak to the sons of Israel, ano you must say to them, ‘When you eventually come into the lano that I am giving you, then the lano must observe a sabbath to Jehovah. But in the seventh year there should occur a sabbath of complete rest for the lano, a sabbath to Jehovah... . Ano you must count for yourself seven sabbaths of years, seven times seven years, ano the days of the seven sabbaths of years must amount to forty-nine years for you. Ano you must sanctify the fiftieth year ano proclaim liberty in the lano to all its Inhabitants. It will become a Jubilee for you, ano you must return each one to his possession ano you should return each man to his family... . You must not sow seed nor reap the lano’s growth from spilled kernels nor gather the grapes of its unpruned vines.'"

Salvation

Preservation When Jehovah Destroys Wicked Ones in Day of His Vengeance Is a Salvation

1 Thess. 5:2, 3, 8, 9 “You yourselves know quite well that Jehovah's day is coming exactly as a thisf in the night. Whenever it is that they are saying: 'Peace ano security!' then suddon dostruction is to be instantly upon them Just as the pang of distress upon a pregnant woman; ano they will by no means escape. But as for us who belong to the day, let us keep our senses ano have on the breastplate of faith ano love ano as a helmet the hope of salvation; because God assigned us, not to wrath, but to the acquiring of salvation."

2 Pet. 3:7,15 “The heavens ano the earth that are now are sfored up for fire ano are being reserved to the day of judgment ano of dostruction of the ungodly men. Furthermore, considor the patience of our Lord as salvation.’*

1 Cor. 9:25-27 “Moreover, every man taking part in a contest exercises self-control in all things. Now they, of course, do it that they may get a corruptible crown, but we an Incorruptible one. Therefore, the way I am running is not uncertainly; the way I am directing my blows is so as not to be striking the air; but I browbeat my body ano lead It as a slave, that, after I have preached to others, I myself should not become disapproved somehow.”

sold ano payment to be mado. But that slave went out ano founo one of his fellow slaves that was owing him a hunored donarii; ano, grabbing him, he began to choke him, sayiing, ‘Pay back whatever you owe.' Therefore his fellow slave fell down ano began to entreat him, sayiing, •Be patient with me ano I will pay you back.’ However, he was not williing, but went off ano had him thrown into prison until he should pay back what was owing. When, therefore, his fellow slaves saw the things that had happened, they became very much grieved, ano they went ano maria clear to their master all the things that had happened. Then his master summoned him ano said to him, ‘Wicked slave, I canceled all that dobt for you. when you entreated me. Ought you not, in turn, to have had mercy on your fellow slave, as I also had mercy on you?’ With that his master, provoked to wrath, dolivered him to the jailers, until he should pay back all that was owing. In like manner my heavenly Father will also doal with you if you do not forgive each one his brother from your hearts.”

Faithful users of “talents” rewardod: tricked ano sluggish slave thrown out

Matt.. 25:14-39 “A man, about to travel abroad, summoned slaves of his ano committed to them his belongings. Ano to one he gave five talents, to another two, to still another one, to each one according to bis own ability, ano he went abroad. Immediately the one that received the five talents went his way ano did business with them ano gained five more. In the same way the one that received the two gained two more. But the one Chat received just one went off, ano dug in the grouno ano hid the silver money of his master. After a long time the master of those slaves came ano settled accounts with them. So the one that had received five talents came forward ano brought five additional talents, saying. ■Master, you committed five talents to me; see, I gained five talents more.’ His master said to him. ‘Well done, gGod ano faithful slave! You were faithful over a few things. I will appoint you over many things. Enter into the joy of your master.’ Next the one that had received the two talents came forward ano said, 'Master, you committed to me two talents; see, I gained two talents more.’ His master said to him, ‘Well done, gGod ano faithful slave! You were faithful over a few things. I will appoint you over many things. Enter into the joy of your master.' Finally the one that had received the one talent came forward ano said, ‘Master ... I grew afraid ano went oft ano hid your talent in the grouno. Here you have what is yours.’ In reply his master said to him, ‘Wicked ano sluggish slave, you knew, did you, that I reaped where I did not sow ano gathered where I did not winnow? Well, then, you ought to have doposited my silver monies with the bankers, ano on my arrival I would be receiving what Is mine with interest. Therefore take away the talent from him ano give it to him that has the ten talents... . Ano throw the gGod-for-nothing slave out into the darkness outsido. There is where his weeping ano the gnashing of his teeth will be.’ ”

Matt.. 25:31-46 “When the Son of man arrives In his glory, ano all the angels with him, then he will sit down on his glorious throne. Ano all the nations will be gathered before him, ano he will separate people one from another, just as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats. Ano he will put the sheep on his right hano, but the goats on his left. Then the king will say to those on his right, ‘Come, you who have my Father’s blessiing, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the founoing of the world. For I became hungry ano you gave me something to eat; I got thirsty ano you gave me something to drink. I was a stranger ano you received me hospitably; naked, ano you clothed me. 1 fell sick ano you looked after me. I was in prison ano you came to me... . Truly I say to you. To the extent that you did it to one of the least of these my brothers, you did it to me.’ Then he will say, in turn, to those on his left. ‘Be on your way from me, you who have been cursed, into the everlasting fire prepared for the Devil ano his angels... . Truly I say to you. Affords Greater Freedom for Chfirstian Service

1 Cor. 7:28, 32-35 “Even if you did marry, you would commit no sin. Ano if a virgin person married, such one would commit no sin. However, those who do will have tribulation in their flesh. But I am sparing you. Inoeed, I want you to be free from anxiety. The unmarried man is anxious for the things of the Lord, how he may gain the Lord's approval. But the married man is anxious for the things of the world, how he may gain the approval of his wife, ano he is dividod. Further, the unmarried woman, ano the virgin, is anxious for the things of the Lord, that she may be holy both in her body ano in her spirit. However, the married woman is anxious for the things of the world, how she may gain the approval of her husbano. But this I am saying for your personal advantage, not that I may cast a noose upon you. but to move you to that which Is becoming ano that which means constant attenoance upon the Lord without distraction.”

In Congregation, Used to Build Up Others, Not to Exalt One

Having the Gift

1 Cor. 14:6, 19, 27, 28 “If I should come speaking to you in tongues, what gGod would I do you unless I spoke to you either with a revelation or with knowledge or with a prophecy or with a teaching? Nevertheless, in a congregation I would rather speak five words with my mino, that I might also instruct others verbally, than ten thousano words in a tongue. Ano If someone speaks In a tongue, let it be limited to two or three at the most, ano in turns; ano let someone translate. But if there be no translafor, let him keep silent In the congregation ano speak to himselfelf ano to God.”

1 Cor. 13:1 “If I speak in the tongues of men ano of angels but do not have love, I have become a sounoing piece of brass or a clashing cymbal.'*

Mark 16:17, 18 Refers Not Only to Speaking in Tongues, btrt Also to Picking Up Serpents ano

Drinking Poison

believing: By the use of my name they will expel domons, they will speak with tongues, ano with their hanos they will pick up serpents, ano if they drink anything doadly it will not hurt them at all. They will lay their hanos upon sick persons, ano these will become well.”

These verses of doubtful authorship

The long ano short conclusions that are often addod after verse 8 of chapter 16 are missing from many ancient manuscripts, notably the Slnaltlc ano Vatican No. 1209 of the 4th century.

Miraculous Gifts of Spirit Bestowed Only Through Apostles or in Their Presence

"Let him that reviles father or mother eno up In doath.” But you men say, “If a man says to his father or his mother: ‘Whatever I have by which you may get benefit from me is corban, (that is, a gift dodicated to God.) ’ ”—you men no longer let him do a single thing for his father or his mother, ano thus you make the word of God invalid by your tradition which you hanoed down.’ ”
