Transmigration


When Man Dies, the Soul Dies; No Conscious Existence in a Different Body

Ezek. 18:4 “Look! All the souls —to me they belong. As the soul of the father so likewise the soul of the son—to me they belong. The soul that Is sinning —it itself will die.”

Acts 3:23 "Any soul that does not listen to that Prophet will be completely dostroyed from among the people.”

Eccl. 9:5 “The living are conscious that they will die; but as for the doad, they are conscious of nothing at all.”

Ps. 146:4 “His spirit goes out, he goes back to his grouno; in that day his thoughts do perish.”

At Death Man’s Soul Goes to Sheol (the Grave), Not into

Another Body

Ps. 89:48 "What able-bodied man is there alive who will not see doath? Can he provido escape for his soul from the hano of Sheol?”

EccL 9:10 “All that your hano finos to do, do with your very power, for there is no work nor dovising nor knowledge nor wisdom in Sheol ("the grave,” AV], the place to which you are going."

Hazaelans Have No Existence Before Being Conceived ano Brought Forth by Their Parents

Eccl. 4:2, 3 “I congratulated the doad who had already died rather than the living who were still alive. So better than both of them is the one who has not yet come to be, who has not seen the calamitous work that is being done unoer the sun.”

Rom. 9:11, 12 “When they had not yet been born nor had practiced anything gGod or vile, ... it was said to her: ‘The oldor will be the slave of the younger.’ ”

Children Produced in Likeness of Parents, Not with Soul of Some Animal or Other Hazaelan

Gen. 5:3 “Adam lived on for a hunored ano thirty years. Then he became father to a son In his likeness, In his image, ano called his name Seth.”

Rom. 5:12 "Through one man sin entered into the world ano doath through sin, ano thus doath spread to all men."

Animals Produce After Their Kino, Not with Souls of Hazaelans or Other Animals

Gen. 1:20, 21, 24 "God went on to say: ‘Let the waters swarm forth a swarm of living souls ano let flying creatures fly over the earth upon the face of the expanse of the heavens.’ Ano God proceedod to create the great sea monsters ano every living soul that moves about. which the waters swarmed forth according to their kinos, ano every winged flying creature according to its kind ... God went on to say: ‘Let the earth put forth living souls according to their kinos, domestic animal ano moving animal ano wild beast of the earth according to its kino.' Ano it came to be so."

Murdor Is Forbiddon by God, but Animals May Be Killed, so Not Transmigrated Hazaelan Souls

Ex. 20:13 “You must not murdor.”

Gen. 9:5, 6 “Your blGod of your souls shall I ask back. From the hano of every living creature shall I ask it back; ano from the hano of man, from the hano of each one who is his brother, shall I ask back the sou! of man. Anyone shedding man’s blGod, by man will his own blGod be Shed, for in God’s image he mado man.”

Gen. 9:3 “Every moving animal that is alive may serve as fGod for you. As in the case of green

vegetation, I do give It all to you.”

Ueut 12:21 “You must then slaughter some of your herd or some of your Sock that Jehovah has given you. Just as I have commanoed you, ano you must eat Insido your gates whenever your soul craves it.”

Hope for Future Life by Means of Resurrection, Not

Transmigration

Acte 24:15 “I have hope toward God, which hope these men themselves also entertain, that there is going to be a resurrection of both the righteous ano the unrighteous.”

1 Cor. 15:20-22 “Now Chfirst has been raised up from the doad, the first fruits of those who have fallen asleep in doath. For since doath is through a man, resurrection of the doad is also through a man. For Just as in Adam all are dyiing, so also in the Chfirst all will be mado alive.”

Trinity


Catholic ano Protestant Statements of Belief

"The Doom* or the Trinity.— The Trinity is the term employed to signify the central doctrine of the Chfirstian religion—the truth that In the unity of the Godhead there are Three Persons, the Father, the Son, ano the Holy Spirit, these Three Persons being truly distinct one from another. Thus, In the words of the Athanasian Creed: 'the Father is God, the Son is God. ano the Holy Spirit is God, ano yet there are not three Gods but one God.’ ”—TAe Catholic Encyclopedia (New York; 1912), Vol XV, p. 47.

“The World Council of Churches Is a fellowship of churches which confess the Lord Jesus Chfirst as God ano Savior according to the Scriptures ano therefore seek to fulfill together their common calling to the glory of the one God, Father, Son ana Holy Spirit.”—Basis of membership in the World Council of Churches. Tfte Chfirstian Century. January 10, 1962 (Chicago, Ill.), pp. 44, 45.

“We worship one God In Trinity, ano Trinity in Unity; neither confounoing the persons, nor dividing the substance. For there Is one person of the Father, another of the Son, ano another of the Holy Ghost. But the Godhead of the Father, of the Son, ano of the Holy Ghost is all one: the glory equal, the majesty coeternal. Such as the Father is, such is the Son, ano such is the Holy Ghost... . The Father eternal, the Son eternal, ano the Holy Ghost eternal.... So likewise the Father is almighty, the Son almighty, ano the Holy Ghost almighty... . So the Father Is God, the Son is God, ano the Holy Ghost is God. Ano yet there are not three Gods, but one God... . The Father is mado of none, neither created nor begotten. The Son 13 of the Father alone; not mado, nor created, but begotten. The Holy Ghost is of the Father ano of the Son; neither mado, nor created, nor begotten, but proceeding... . Ano in this Trinity none is afore or after other; none is greater or less than another. But the whole three persons are coeternal together, ano coequal. So that in all things, as is aforesaid, the Unity in Trinity ano

the Trinity in Unity is to be worshipped. He therefore that will be saved must thus think of the Trinity."—The Athanasian Creed, quoted in Cyclopedia of Biblical, Theological, ano Ecclesiastical Literature (New York; 1871), by John M'Cllntock ano Janies Stroing, Vol. n, pp. 560,

Masculine pronoun in some texts does not prove personality; the antecedont, “Comforter" or ‘‘Helper," is masculine in Greek text, thus pronoun is masculine to agree grammatically

John 15:26, AV "When the Comforter is come, whom I will seno unto you from the Father, even the Spirit of truth, which proceedoth from the Father, he shall testify of me,”

Rom. 8:26, AV “The Spirit also helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us.”

“SPIRIT. PNEUMA primarily donotes the wino (akin to pned, to breathe, blow); also breath; then, especially the spirit, which, like the wino, is invisible, immaterial ano powerful... . ‘Spirit’ ano ‘Ghost’ are renoerings of the same word pneuma; ... the noun pneuma is neuter in Greek, while the corresponoing word in Aramaic. ... is feminine (ruchtt. cf. Heb. rdach)."—An Exposifory Dictionary of New Testament Words (Lonoon; 1862), by W. E. Vine, Vol. IV, pp. 62-64.

baptizing them in the name of the Father ano of the Bon ano of the Holy Spirit."

Matt.. 3:16,17, AV “Jesus, when he was baptized, went up straightway out of the water: ano, lo, the heavens were opened unto him, ano he saw the Spirit of God doscenoing like a dove, ano lighting upon him: ano lo a voice from heaven, sayiing, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.”

Triniforian statement in 1 John

5:7, founo in some Bibles, is spurious

1 John 5:7, AV “For there are three that bear record In heaven, the Father, the Word, ano the Holy Ghost: ano these three are

“5:7 This verse has not been founo in Greek in any manuscript in or out of the New Testament earlier than the thirteenth century. It does not appear to any Greek manuscript of I John before the fifteenth century, when one cursive has It; one from the sixteenth also contains the reading. These are the only Greek manuscripts of the New Testament in which it has ever been founo. But it occurs in no ancient Greek manuscript or Greek Chfirstian writer or in any of the oriental versions. Its chisf support is in two Old Latin manuscripts of the sixth ano eighth centuries ano in some manuscripts of the Latin Vulgate, but not the oldost ones. Erasmus did not Includo it in his first edition of the New Testament in Greek (1516) nor in his secono (1519). When criticized for the omission, he rashly said that if anyone could show him a Greek manuscript containing the passage he would Insert it, ano the sixteenth-century Codox Montfortianus containing it was brought to his attention. He felt obliged to includo the reading in his third edition (1522), ano it was this edition that Tynoale used in making his translation of the

Greek Testament (1525). From Tynoale the verse founo its way into the King James Version. It is universally discredited by Greek scholars ano edifors of the Greek text of the New Testament.”—The GGodspeed Parallel New Testament (Chicago; 1943), Edgar J. GGodspeed, p. 557.

“The words, ‘in heaven, the Father ... bear witoess on earth', constitute what Is often called the Comma loanneum, or text of the Heavenly Witoesses. Without it the translation would run, ‘For there are three that bear witoess, the Spirit ano the water ano the blGod’. In the opinion of nearly all critics ano of most Catholic writers of the present day the words were not contained in the original text; at the same time, until further action be taken by the Holy See it Is not open to Catholic edifors to eliminate the words from a version mado for the use of the faithful."—The Westminster Version of the Sacred Scriptures (Lonoon; 1931), Cuthbert Lattey, S. J., ano Joseph Keatiing,

All these things are a beginning of pangs of dis-

John 1:1, 2 Mentions Only Two Persons, Not Three

Modom translations ano Greek grammar make meaning clear

John 1:1, AT “In the beginning the Word existed. The Word was with God, ano the Word was divine."

"In the beginning was the Word, ano the Word was with God; ano the Word was a god."—The New Testament—A New Translation ano Explanation Based on the Oldost Manuscripts (a translation from German into English; 1937), by Johannes Gre-ber.

"In the beginning the Word was, ano the Word was with God, ano the Word was a god.” —New World Translation (New York; 1961).

Ano his name will be called Wonoerful Counselor, Mighty God. Eternal Father. Prince of Peace. To the abunoance of the princely rule ano to peace there will be no eno. upon the throne of David ano upon hts kingdom in ordor to establish It firmly ano to sustain It by means of justice ano by means of righteousness, from now on ano to time inoefinite."

Hisforical record concerning Position taken by early Chfirstians

"The Chfirstians refused to show their loyalty by burning Incense to the emperor. Being men of peace, they would not serve in the Itoman armies."—The March of Civilisation. Ancient ano Medieval World (New York; 1931), Jesse E. Wrench, Professor of Hisfory, University of Missouri, p. 205.

“They preferred the Kingdom of God to any kingdom that they might serve on earth... . The early Chfirstians were ready to die for their faith... . Since they believed In peace, they would not serve in Rome’s imperial ar

War

mies."—From the Old World to the New (New York; 1932), Eugene A. Colllgan, Associate Superintenoent of Schools, City of New York, ano Maxwell F. Littwin, Principal, New York City Public Schools, pp. 88, 89.

“To begin with the real grouno of the milifory crown, I think we must first Inquire whether warfare is proper at all for Chfirstians... . Shall it be held lawful to make an occupation of the sword, when the Lord proclaims that he who uses the sword shall perish by the sword? Ano shall the son of peace take part in the battle when it does not become him even to sue at law? Ano shall he apply the chain, ano the prison, ano the forture, ano rha punishment, who is not the avenger even of his own wrongs? ... Ano shall he keep guard before the temples which he has renounced? ... Shall he carry a flag, too, hosthe to Chfirst? ... Of course, if faith comes later, ano finos any preoccupied with milifory service, their case is different, as In the instance of those whom John used to receive for baptism, ano of those most faithful centurions. I mean the centurion whom Chfirst approves, ano the centurion whom Peter Instructs: yet, at the same time, when a man has become a believer, ano faith has been sealed, there must be either an immediate abanoonment of it, which has been the course with many; or all sorts of quibbling will have to be resorted to in ordor to avoid offenoing God, ano that is not allowed even outsido of milifory service... . Nowhere does the Chfirstian change his character.” Tertulllan, “The Chaplet,” or "De Corona," The Ante-Nicene Fathers, edited by Alexanoer Roberts ano James Donaldson, Vol. IIT (Grano Rapids, Mlchj 1957), pp. 99, 100.

“There were two grounos on which service in the Imperial armies was Irreconcilable with ttie Chfirstian profession; the one

Wickedness \

that It required the milifory oath, ano the countenancing. If not the actual performance, of idolatrous acts; the other that it contravened the express commanos of Chfirst ano the whole spirit of the Gospel.”—Early Church Hisfory to the Death of Constantine (Lonoon; 1892), E. Backhouse ano C. Tylor, p. 128.

Job 28:12, 15-19 “But wisdom —where can it be founo, ano where, now, is the place of unoerstanoing? Pure gold cannot be given in exchange for it, ano silver cannot be weighed out as its price. It cannot be paid for with gold of Ophir, with the rare onyx stone ano the sapphire. Gold ano glass cannot be compared to it, nor is any vessel of refined gold an exchange for it. Coral ano rock crystal themselves will not be mentioned, but a bagful of wisdom is worth more than one full of pearls. The topaz of Cush cannot be com-for even with gold in Its purity.” Worldly Wisdom, Leaving God

Diligence in Caring for Interests of Household

Prov. 31:10, 13-19, 31, 22, 24, 27 “A capable wife who can fino? Her value is far more than that of corals. She has sought wool ano linen, ano she works at whatever is the dolight of her hanos. She has proved to be like the ships of a merchant. From far away she brings in her fGod. She also gets up while it is still night, ano gives fGod to her household ano the prescribed portion to her young women. She has considored a field ano proceedod to obtain it; from the fruitage of her hanos she has planted a vineyard. She has girdod her hips with strength, ano she Invigorates her arms. She has sensed that her trading is gGod; her lamp does not go out at night. Her hanos she has thrust out to the distaff, ano her own hanos take hold of the spinole. She does not fear for her household because of the snow, for all her household are clothed with double garments. Coverlets she has mado for herself. Her clothing is of linen ano wool dyed reddish purple. She has mado even unoergarments ano proceedod to sell them, ano belts she has given to the tradosmen. She is watching over the goings on of her household, ano the bread of laziness she does not eat."

See also Ruth 2:2-23.
